title: rich kind joe wicks inspiring mum
story: If he wasn’t already a household name before this began, Joe, with his spontaneous and generous offer of a daily free PE class, has certainly become one now.A whopping million people tuned in during the first week. He has stuck to his promise and shown up every day, despite having to have surgery on his wrist and being in evident pain at times.Not only that, but he is donating the revenue from advertising on the show to the NHS. He embodies the perfect combination of qualities required to be a good business person: Do all you can, give something back and be ethical.In the past six weeks he has made more than £.million as new fans snapped up his -Day Plan well-being programme from his Body Coach site.But I really don’t think this was about making more money or becoming more famous.Bear in mind that Joe, who is only , has already made millions following the success of his cookbook and his online fitness classes.He really didn’t need to make more money or be more famous.I honestly believe he just wants children everywhere to experience the joy of fitness.There is a lot to like about Joe. But one thing I love about him is that one of his first le goals was to buy his mum, Raquela, a house. Having grown up on a council estate in Surrey, with Raquela and brothers Nikki and George, Joe always dreamed of being able to spend his earnings on his mum after she supported him in the earliest days of his career.“My mum’s always lived in a council house. We’ve never had mortgages. It wasn’t on the radar for us.“So when I could take that money I earned from that book and say ‘Mum, I’m buying your house. It’s yours’, that was an amazing moment for me.”Joe didn’t have an easy childhood. He has spoken about his father Gary still struggling with heroin addiction. But rather than repeating history, he actively decided to take a dferent path.He found exercise as a coping method. “I used exercise probably as a way to manage my feelings,” he has said.He said: “Because of my dad’s addiction, and the damage I saw it cause, me and Nikki steered clear of it. We weren’t smoking weed. We were training, exercising and playing sport. Along the line, I decided that wasn’t going to be my destiny.”Things in le either crush you or make you the person you were always meant to be. The strength of character it takes to turn your back on the path chosen by your first and most important role model — your dad — is immense.It would be so easy for him to have chosen the same path as his father or use his father’s addiction as an excuse for not making the most of his le.Joe has said he tries not to dwell on his past nor judge his dad. All that matters to him now is being happy and looking forward.The moral of this story is: Put the graft in, keep pushing yourself and never give up.But one of the many likeable things about Joe is how readily he credits Raquela for her role in his success, saying she taught them “right and wrong”, while his dad was “in and out of rehab”.She must be a hell of a woman to have brought up three boys so well. Joe and Nikki work together now, which is testament to the strength of their family ties.Knowing all this about Joe makes it all the more amazing he found his happy ever after when he married his model we Rosie in , and the pair now have two adorable children — Indie who’s  months and four-month-old Marley.It would be easy to resent his success. But how could anyone wish Joe anything other than happiness, given what he has overcome and also his approach to le I’m as keen as the next person for the lockdown to end and for normal le to resume – at least as much as it possibly can.But when I read about the fliers advertising mass gatherings, promising picnics and live music in cities across the UK this weekend, I couldn’t believe my eyes.At least eight events were being organised by anti-vaxxing group UK Freedom Movement, which claims the lockdown is illegal.Its posters headlined “UK Mass Gathering” said: “We say no to the coronavirus bill, no to mandatory vaccines, no to the new normal and no to the unlawful lockdown.”It is also urged people to gather in a major park in the eight locations, including London, Sheffield and Edinburgh, to “bring a picnic, some music and let’s have some fun and say yes to le”.Yes, lockdown measures are extreme and yes, we all want them to relax and for normality to .But what the organisers of this are failing to realise is that you can’t protest or demonstrate against a virus.And while there is so much still left for us to understand about how this particular virus works, to attend a mass gathering in protest seems like a fool’s errand.This event is clearly organised by idiots, for idiots.If only we’d all been quick-witted enough to self-isolate with someone who knows how to do our hair, like Kate Moss, who has been hunkering down with A-lister stylist James Brown.That said, Kate is an absolute beauty and clearly a supermodel, whether she is having a good hair day or a bad one.As luck would have it I am currently living with my mum.She has done a grand job dyeing my roots so far, but I think a blow-dry may be beyond her remit.Luckily, with a pandemic going on, and staff to worry about, I have more important things to think about than my hair.Twitter has been among the first companies to announce that it will not be bringing employees back into the workplacethey would prefer to work from home.And for more and more people, home is likely to be the new workplace – with meetings taking place on screens.The past few weeks have shown us that as long as people have a laptop and wi-fi, many can work from home.For lots of us, being allowed to do so means we save loads of money on travel and hundreds of hours of commuting time, while massively reducing our carbon footprint.And we’ll never have to buy a stale sandwich again.Meanwhile, companies will save a fortune on rent.All in all, this new way of working, for those who can do it, makes sense.Over the past few weeks we have all become much more aware of people’s proximity to us.And yes, with streets that have fewer cars than ever before, no doubt some of us are stepping into the road to avoid another pedestrian who could come within two metres of us.But police have felt the need to issue warnings to pedestrians not to walk into the road to dodge fellow pedestrians because it is dangerous .Seriously, is such a warning really necessary I know we have all been in lockdown for a while but surely we haven’t taken leave of our common sense and will remember to look left and right when we cross the road . . . won’t we It’s now been eight weeks since our Thursday night Clap For Carers began. And looking at this photo of Boris Johnson outside No from Thursday, it’s a good reminder that things are changing all the time.When you compare it to the picture taken of him just days before he was admitted to hospital it really shows the big dference a few weeks make.He looks more or less back to his old self. Also, it’s really cheering to see new mum Carrie looking so well and so happy.We seem to be seeing lots of people in their swim-wear at the moment, with not a. pool in sight!Normally I try to give thanks for my strong and able body rather than worrying too much about what it looks like.But it’s hard not to feel a tad wistful looking at photos of Kimberley Garner, who looks so fit and gorgeous she’d no doubt be awarded swimwear body of the week,such an award existed. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: oxford coronavirus vaccine uk
story: DRUGS giant AstraZeneca will make  million doses of the Oxford coronavirus vaccine by Septemberit works - and the UK will be the first to get it. Business Secretary Alok Sharma announced yesterday evening that a global licensing deal had been signed between Oxford University and the pharma firm as part of a £million plan to vaccinate half the UK population.The firm will make million doses of the vaccine over timeit proves to prevent the infection - and half of Brits would be in line to get one.In order to succeed as soon as possible, Mr Sharma announced a fresh £m in cash for the two universities to scale up production of their ground-breaking potential vaccines.£. million is earmarked for Oxford and £.million for Imperial.This will mean the UK will be the first country to get access to the Oxford vaccine, should it be successful.Oxford has finished its first phase of human trials this week - with everyone planned having received their vaccine doses on schedule.Imperial are on track to start their trial in June, with a second one by October.It came as:Business Secretary Mr Sharma said: Our scientists are at the forefront of vaccine development. This deal with AstraZeneca means thatthe Oxford University vaccine works, people in the UK will get the first access to it, helping to protect thousands of lives.The agreement will deliver  million doses in total, ensuring that in addition to supporting our own people, we are able to make the vaccines available to developing countries at the lowest possible cost.The UK continues to lead the global response to find a vaccine, and the government is backing our scientists to do this as quickly as possible.And Health Secretary Matt Hancock added: Our injection of a further £ million for a #coronavirus vaccine is a great step forward in our national effort.However, Boris Johnson has been stark with the public - admitting we may not get a vaccine.Hes said in the past: A mass vaccine or treatment may be more than a year away. Indeed, in a worst-case scenario, we may never find a vaccine.However, Professor Sarah Gilbert, who is working on a vaccine with a team at the university, is confident it will work and says it could be ready in just months.As the nation faces the reality of living for months with coronavirus restrictions, a successful vaccine holds the key to the end of isolation measures.Currently, there is no vaccine or treatment available for Covid- but doctors across the globe are testing current anti-viral drugs to seethey can beat coronavirus.On Sunday, Mr Sharma revealed that six more drugs would go into tests to seethey can have an effect on coronavirus symptoms.About  research groups are pursuing vaccines with nearly a dozen in early stages of human trials or poised to start.Microsoft billionaire Bill Gates, for example, has committed hundreds of millions of dollars to developing a vaccine through the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation.To receive The Suns Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.

title: get businesses open coronavirus
story: As the chief of the OBR made crystal-clear yesterday, the scarring will be permanent unless society can be ed to some semblance of normality as soon as is safely possible.Which means serious thought must now be given to getting businesses open:that involves masks in workplaces and Perspex separations in cafes and bars, so be it. It might feel strange at first, but we’ll get used to it.Militant unions telling teachers they should refuse to go back to work must also urgently rethink their stance.Reopening schools is obviously essentialwe are to prevent the poorest and most vulnerable children falling behind — new research reveals that better-off children are spending a whopping  per cent more time each day on education than those from poorer homes.But as parents can only go back to work once their kids are in class, it’s also the only way to kickstart the economy.Of course, there will always be an element of risk to getting society up and running again. Even before coronavirus, it would have been impossible for anyone to guarantee the safety of every worker every day.But the Government has stressed it’s “extremely unlikely” a school could be the source of a Covid- outbreak.And given the risks frontliners take every single day, that assurance should be good enough for teaching unions.WE welcome the news that the Government plans to push ahead with legislation to end free movement and replace it with a points-based immigration system before the end of this year.The new system is exactly what Brexit-voting Sun readers wanted: it will let us welcome the brightest and best — including doctors, nurses and carers — to the UK based on what they have to offer, not where they come from.And it’s logical to get it introduced quickly so businesses have time to prepare before the transition period ends.Let’s hope MPs have the sense to back the bill.WE can all sleep a little more soundly in our beds now the Government looks set to hit its target of recruiting , contact-tracers by the end of next week.It’s been obvious for a long time that widespread testing and tracing is the best way to contain the virus: all the countries that have fared best have been doing it from the start.But thanks to dodgy advice from Public Health England, Boris and his ministers gave up on it back in March.What a relief they’ve finally seen the light.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: points based immigration system parliament
story: It will let the UK choose migrants according to their work skills and mark the end of the EU’s free movement.Ministers want it ready as soon as possible so firms can prepare for rule changes.Home Secretary Priti Patel said: “For the first time in decades, the UK will have the power to determine who comes to this country.”She added: “We know this will mean changes in the way businesses operate and recruit, but by doing this now we are giving businesses time to prepare and adapt as the economic recovery gathers pace.”Visas for workers and their families have been extended before the new laws to help fight the coronavirus crisis, and current EU citizens in the UK have also had their right to stay protected.Ms Patel added: “Our new points-based system is firmer, fairer, and simpler. It will attract the people we need to drive our economy forward and lay the foundation for a high wage, high skill, high productivity economy”The new immigration system will make it easier and quicker for medical professionals around the world to work in the NHS through a new fast-track NHS visa.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: primary school pupils urged in hoops
story: THE first pictures of how school could look for millions of children from next month has been revealed - with children told to stand inside hoops to play in the playground.Holywell Village First School , Northumberland, have released pictures of their social distancing plans for when pupilsto classrooms on June .But the school has come under fire after now-deleted Facebook post seen bysaid pupils showed the first pictures of so-called play bubbles where kids will have to stay when they go outside.A photo demonstrating how this would look showed hula hoops lined across the playground and marked with an X.And one way systems will be in place inside corridors too to keep kids apart.Toys, soft furnishings and books have also been removed from classrooms, while outside play equipment will not be able to be used as there are not enough members of staff to clean it afterwards.Parents also raised concern about strict rules regarding use of the toilet and children having to do their own first aidthey scrape themselves.The post said kids will be given specic time slots and will not be allowed to leave the classroom outside of their allocated toilet times.It said: If they fall over or have a toileting accident they will be encouraged to change themselves and clean their scrape or cut.We have sourced PPEwhich is for use only for staff protection should a child vomit, not for trips, falls or scrapes.If it is not possible for the child to clean themselves in the event of an accident, the parent will be called to collect them so they can do that at home.The school said it did not wish to make such drastic changes but that it was doing everything it can to adhere to government guidance to keep staff and children as safe as possible.The Facebook post, which was shared thousands of times, was deleted after parents hit back.People raised concern that no hot meals would be provided, that parents would be banned from entering the building and that children as young as four will have to learn more independently due to teachers having to keep a two-metre distance.One parent, Kristina Richards, , told : How on earth can children in reception and year one have an allocated toilet time  They are young kids andthey need to go to the toilet then they need to.No child aged   should have to clean up their own cuts. Andthey can’t do it then a parent will be called. Whatthat parent is now back to work Does that mean this child has to wait maybe an hour until a parent arrives to change their child’s soiled clothes or clean their bleeding legs  It’s ludicrous.However, the Government has stressed that primary school kids will not be expected to stay two metres apart at all times.The guidance states: We know that, unlike older children and adults, early years and primary age children cannot be expected to remain  metres apart from each other and staff. In deciding to bring more children back to early years and schools, we are taking this into account.Instead they should stay in small classes of , and make sure they wash their hands more.Regular cleaning will also have to happen, too.In France, a recent picture showed nursery school children sitting alone in their own playground isolation sections.The picture, taken in the northern town of Tourcoing, on the Belgium border, shows a group of boys and girls being kept away from each other using areas marked out in chalk.Back in the UK, Education Secretary Gavin Williamson said yesterday that both primary and secondary school pupils couldto school in just two weeks time, with plans for students in Reception and Years , ,  and  to .He also sought to reassure parents concerned about pupils ing to school, insisting that the governments decision-making is based on the best scientic advice with children at the very heart of everything we do.

title: uk weather forecast this week met office temperatures
story: The weather is perfectly timed for the eased lockdown measures, with sunshine and clear skies forecast to spread across the week.Met Office meteorologist John Grfiths told Sun Online that conditions were generally going to be dry and fine.He said: It will gradually warm up over the next few days. Monday could see a high of C - possibly C - in the south east, Mr Grfiths explained.England and Wales could see temperatures exceeding C and as high as C in some spots as temperatures keep climbing throughout the week.BBC meteorologist Tomasz Schafernaker said: The temperatures, on Sunday, given a bit of sunshine in the south of the country could exceed  degrees and the current indications are that as we head into next week its going to feel like June or July.Met Office weather maps show temperatures hitting C in London by Tuesday, with similar sunny conditions throughout the south east. Temperatures are likely to hit C on Wednesday.Meteorologist Nicola Maxey said: We are slowly seeing day-on-day warming and we are seeing temperatures pick up, certainly by Sunday in London when well see temperatures of  or C.She added: By the time we get to the middle of next week, temperatures will be in the s and we could even start seeing them up towards the mid-s.We will be seeing theof warmer weather and temperatures above average for this time of year.Although some rain and showers is predicated in the north, the rest of the country should remain mainly dry over the weekend.The outlook for Sunday to Tuesday will be increasingly warm with long sunny periods, the Met Office predicts.Similar predictions were echoed by the national weather services long range report, which said: Temperatures look to take an upward trend over the next two weeks with most areas becoming warm, especially in the south and east.Most places should remain largely dry with plenty of brightness or sunshine as well as light winds.The conditions are a relief from the cold snap experienced this week with overnight temperatures on Thursday plummeting well below zero in some areas.Katesbridge in Northern Ireland saw its lowest temperature ever recorded in May on Thursday morning at minus .C, The Met Office reported.The change in temperature will be a good excuse for Brits to make the most of unlimited exercise and sunbathing opportunities in public parks and beaches.The UK has seen some great weather in the past few weeks, despite lockdown restrictions limiting Brits to leaving the house for essentials only.And with many beauty spots reopening across the country, people will be heading to beaches and natural parks to enjoy the sunshine on next weeks Bank Holiday weekend.To receive The Suns Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.Under new Government guidelines, Brits can now travel anywhere in England by car with members of their own household - so long as theyon the same day.They must also ensure they keep m apart from others at all times.According to the Met Offices long range weather forecast, sunny weather could remain right up until June .A spokesperson said: Although with low confidence, this period looks to stay largely dry and fine with bright or sunny spells for many.

title: bars beaches packed europe coronavirus lockdown
story: BARS and beaches were packed across Europe yesterday as the Continent looks to get back to normal after lockdown.Italy and Spain are further easing coronavirus restrictions today after both countries recorded their lowest daily death tolls for two months.Italy recorded  new Covid- deaths yesterday, the lowest since the nationwide lockdown was imposed on March .And in Spain it was , the first time in two months it has been below .Both countries had more than  deaths a day at the height of the outbreak.The UKs  deaths was also its lowest daily toll since March, but lockdown measures here are not being lted yet.In Italy today, more businesses including shops, bars and hairdressers opened their doors for the first time in two months.Churches were also allowed to hold services including at St Peters Basilica where Pope Francis led a mass celebrating the th birthday of John Paul II.The government had wanted them to stay shut until the end of May but backed down under pressure from regional governors who threatened to begin reopening anyway.Sardinia, Veneto and Calabria have said they will push for maximum easing of measures as soon as possible.However, travel between regions and into Italy is still banned until at least June .Spain is set for a shopping bonanza as the annual sales are due to go ahead despite social distancing fears.Even in Madrid and Barcelona - which have not yet fully entered Phase  of exiting lockdown - smaller shops will be allowed to welcome customers without an appointment.And outside the two big cities, people will be allowed to gather outdoors in groups of ten.In Malaga, cafe owners were seen measuring the distance between tables as they prepared to welcome customers back today.And the islands of Formentera and Cabrera in the Balearics, and La Graciosa, El Hierro and La Gomera in the Canary Islands, will be allowed to skip ahead to Phase  which allows the reopening of shopping centres and gatherings of up to  people.But PM Pedro Sanchez said he will ask Parliament to extend the state of emergency until late June.The tourist industry is set to lose its critical summer season with foreign visitors still not allowed.Mr Sanchez said: Spain needs tourism. But tourism needs security. It needs health guarantees.Meanwhile Belgium is to begin reopening primary and secondary schools today under strict conditions to keep children and teachers apart.Portugal, Greece, Denmark and Ireland are also easing their lockdown measures by degrees.It comes after people across Europe headed to parks and the coast at the weekend to enjoy their new freedoms as the worst-hit continent begins to emerge from the tough restrictions.Beaches were packed in Greece, and surfers flocked to newly reopened Lacanau in France which had been shut for two months.Parks around Paris and Annecy were also heaving with sunbathers, while outdoor cafes were busy with customers in Germany.Over the weekend parasols and sun-loungers started to appear on coastlines in Italy ahead of the expected reopening.Despite the falling death figures, Dr Hans Kluge of the World Health Organisation warned countries should be planning for a second wave of infection.He said: This is not a time for celebration, its a time for preparation.Authorities in many countries have asked people to show restraint and not to throng public spaces like beaches as they are made accessible again.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: dad kawasaki coronavirus good morning britain
story: THE dad of a five-year-old girl left fighting for le in hospital after developing Kawasaki disease has described the agony of his daughters intensive care battle.Scarlett Roberts, from Wakefield, West Yorks, fell ill with the bug just weeks after beating coronavirus and was pictured by dad Piers hooked up to le-saving equipment at Leeds General Infirmary.She was initially given just a  per cent chance of survival, but speaking on Good Morning Britain today Piers said Scarlett has made vast improvements over the last  hours.He said: Since yesterday afternoon shes made vast improvements, in an illness which we still dont fully understand and I can only hope is rare.We understand that its linked to coronavirus, we hope with all our hearts it is a rare condition.Its been the worst situation Ive been put in and my pain pales in comparison to her mothers pain whos been at her bedside all day long.Kawasaki disease inflames blood vessels and is believed to be an adverse reaction to coronavirus.There have currently been around  cases of the disease in the UK and one child is believed to have died.Piers, a teacher and former nurse, said he believes parents need to be given more information on the disease before making a decision on whether totheir children to school next month.He said: As a parent and as a teacher I understand its essential kids get back to school as soon as is safely possible.Schools up and down the country are doing everything they can to make it possible.Teachers want to teach, parents want kids to be in school. The social and emotional benefits let alone the health benefits are absolutely essential.But trust must be restored to parents and teachers. Risk cannot be eliminated entirely butthese are complications which are potentially there and the science is emerging we must understand that.The disease is also known as mucocutaneous lymph node syndrome.According to the NHS, the disease primarily affects children under five years of age.The blood vessels become swollen which can lead to complications in the coronary arteries .Kawasaki disease can cause aneurysms which can lead to a heart attack and heart disease.These the signs to look out for are:He said Scarlett contracted Covid- in school before the lockdown, and described his daughter as fit and well six weeks before she suddenly suffered multi-organ failure.His aunt, June, also shared the heartbreaking picture of the five-year-old hooked up to a ventilator.She wrote on Twitter: This is my five-year-old great niece. She was fit and healthy until a mild bout of Covid- five weeks ago from which she appeared to recover.She is now in ICU with a Kawasaki inflammatory response.She is off the ventilator but has developed heart problems.It was revealed yesterday that an eight-month-old baby died from the coronavirus-linked Kawasaki disease, becoming the UK’s youngest known victim.Little Alexander Parsons died on April  from the rare childhood illness which inflames blood vessels.Medics have renamed the deadly condition as PIMS-TS, in the battle against Covid-.Englands health service had alerted at the end of April that cases of children in intensive care with a multi-system inflammatory state were rising.Children were displaying overlapping symptoms of severe COVID-, toxic shock syndrome and Kawasaki disease.

title: primary school kids not coronavirus super spreaders major study
story: PRIMARY school children are not coronavirus super spreaders, a major study shows.Researchers from Australia found that kids are unlikely to transmit Covid- between each other or to adults.And the research is now being considered by UK Government advisers as they consider how to get children back into classrooms safely ahead of June .Previous studies have suggested that younger children are likely to only contract a mild form of coronavirus and do not play a major role in the spread of the disease.However the Australian study is is believed to be the only major study to look at transmission in primary schools.The researchers said their findings “do suggest that spread of Covid- within NSW schools has been very limited and transmission “appears considerably less than seen for other respiratory viruses, such as influenza”.They concluded that the data “suggests that children are not the primary drivers of Covid- spread in schools or in the community.This is consistent with data from international studies showing low rates of disease in children and suggesting limited spread among children and from children to adults.”The NSW health minister, Brad Hazzard, said the new report showed “schools are amongst the safest places to be… and that obviously is a very important message to all of us who are parents”.Despite this, some scientists believes the fact Australia has a hotter climate in Europe may play a part in lower levels of infection.However, the results have been supported by early data from countries such as Denmark and Norway which shows that the re-opening of schools has not triggered a spike in the disease.A senior member of the Sage sub-committee on schools, known as the Children’s Task and Finish Working Group, told Thethat the study is being considered by Government advisers.It comes amid a long row between unions and the Government about whether or not its right for children in reception, years one and six in England to go back to primary school from June .Critics say its not enough time and are concerned having kids back will see the rate of the virus spread creep up again.Ministers hope reopening schools will be a key step in getting Britain moving again as the country emerges from almost two months of coronavirus lockdown.Kids will have classroom limits, spaced out desks and staggered classes and year groups in on dferent days.Just yesterday, Michael Gove promised that children and teachers will be as safe as possible in schools.The Cabinet Office minister told the BBC yesterday: Yes, teachers will be safe in schools. I talked to the Chief Scientic Adviser yesterday.Running through the figures, the R number, we are confident that children and teachers will be safe, providing the right measures are in place.He added that it is extremely unlikely that any school will be the source of a Covid- outbreak.We know that school settings are not the source of infection that some have feared we know that they can be made safe and appropriate working places, he said.But when grilled on the claims he stressed: you can never eliminate risk and added: There is always, always, always, in any loosening of these restrictions, a risk of people catching the coronavirus.Dr Soumya Swaminathan, the World Health Organisation’s Chief Scientist, also said on Sunday that “there have not been big outbreaks in schools” and the early results of studies are “very reassuring”.She said that “the risks to children are extremely low with this infection, and there have not been many cases described of children transmitting it to others, particularly within school settings”.Therevealed that Sage - the Governments scientic advisory group - is preparing to publish its own evidence in the coming days which will set out the thinking behind recommending that schools reopen gradually.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: david hockney blasts guardian newspaper coronavirus smoking
story: ARTIST David Hockney has attackednewspaper for failing to print a letter he wrote setting out his argument in favour of smoking.Hockney, a keen smoker, has previously described smoking bans in enclosed public spaces as the most grotesque piece of social engineering.Hockney has suggested smoking helps protect people from Covid-.He became embroiled in a row withyesterday when it refused to published his thoughts on smoking and coronavirus.He branded the paper cowardly and claimed it cannot face aspects of his argument.He added: Its shocking that their agenda doesnt allow them to engage in open debate on this.Hockney pointed out that Greece has seen one of the lowest coronavirus death rates in Europe despite having an above average number of smokers.In a letter published in the Mail last month, he said: Could it not be that smokers have developed an immune system to this virus With all these figures coming outresearch in China its beginning to look like that to me.Im serious and remember cigars and cigarettes are vegan.The newspaper said he was referring to research in China on the numbers of smokers being treated with Covid- in hospitals.To back up his argument, a team at Pitié-Salpêtrière hospital in Paris found the infection rate for smokers among Covid- outpatients and inpatients was signicantly lower than for non-smokers.Only . per cent of the coronavirus patients were smokers, while . per cent of the generation population smoke regularly.The research said nicotine was the likely reason while stressing that using tobacco remained a danger to public health.However the World Health Organisation said the French findings were not consistent with what we are seeing in other countries.Public Heath England issued a warning last month that smokers were putting themselves at much greater risk of developing severe disease from the virus.Deborah Arnott, chief executive of the charity Action On Smoking And Health rejected the artists comments.David Hockney is a very heavy smoker...but this is risky advice for others to take, she said.Quitting smoking has immediate benefits.If you quit, endothelialin the linings of small arteries in the blood system improves rapidly.She said endothelial dys was implicated in Covid- and smokers therefore were at higher risk of complications.Advice published by the National Institute For Health And Care Excellence strongly encourages smokers with severe respiratory disease to quit because of coronavirus.Dr Sanjay Agrawal, consultant in respiratory and intensive care medicine, previously said: Doctors should be strongly encouraging smokers with chronic obstructive pulmonary diseaseto quit.In fact they should be encouraging all smokers to quit, as early evidence from China shows that smokers who contract Covid- are more likely to develop severe disease, to end up in intensive care and to die.Smokers should try to quit without delay.The benefits from quitting are immediate, including increased oxygen supply to the lungs, reduced risk of respiratory infections, and improvements in blood pressure.Longer-term benefits include signicant reductions in the risk of developing cancer, heart disease and COPD.Hockney is currently painting in Normandy, France, which he has said is a lot more smoker-friendly than England.ANews  Media spokesman said: We receive hundreds of letters a day and cannot publish them all. However, we are not aware of recently receiving a letter from David Hockney.To receive The Suns Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: meghan markle prince harry international royals
story: The Duke and Duchess of Sussex shocked the world after quitting the Royal Family before moving to Canada then onto LA.But royal expert Katie Nicholl today said it was inevitable that the couple would relocate - but admitted the speed of their move had surprised everybody.She told Australian website Honey: I was told from a very early stage in their courtship, they had told a friend of Harrys that Meghan met quite early on that they wanted to international roving royals and that was going to be their focus.This is not a couple who like to sit around and twiddle their thumbs. They move quickly and they do seem in quite a hurry to do their thing.She added: They didnt want to just be stuck in one place. Part of their vision is to be making a dference on the world stage and that entails being international.Since they married two years ago, the couple conducted royal trips to Australia and Africa, along with welcoming baby Archie before quitting the Firm.They had initially planned on splitting their time between North America and the UK but have since moved to LA.And they have continued their jetsetting lestyle - flying to private speaking engagements and reportedly taking Tyler Perrys private plane to move to LA.The couple are now settling into their new home in LA - although reports have surfaced that Prince Harry is feeling rudderless.The -year-old, was stripped of his military appointments and no longer represents the Queen on public tours.Meanwhile, Meghan has already scored her first post-royal gig - narrating a Disney Plus documentary about elephants.And it has since been claimed singer Adele has befriended the couple.Among other A-lister neighbours, Meghan and Harry are surrounded by stars including Katy Perry, Jenner Lawrence and Sir Elton John.The Duke and Duchess of Sussex are currently living with one-year-old baby Archie in an eight-bedroom, -bathroom LA property that is owned by -year-old tycoon Tyler Perry.The luxury  postcode pad, where they are currently on lockdown, is also close to Rod Stewart and Samuel L Jackson.Now the duchess, , is a stone’s throw away from her tennis best friend Serena Williams, along with her actress pal Abigail Spencer, among many others.Back in Britain, the couple have started to repay the £.m spent on refurbishing their home in the UK, Frogmore Cottage.Their five-bedroom property was a wedding gt from the Queen and is currently empty.It is understood to be a rental-plus agreement where they are paying £, a month - more than the commercial rate so the excess is used to pay off the renovation bill.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: schools could go back before others
story: SCHOOLS in some areas maybefore others, a minister suggested last night.Policing minister Kit Malthouse was asked about changing lockdown measures dferently across the country - as the rate of spread ies.Ministers have left the door open to changing things regionallythere are vast dferences in the R rate of infections between regions.At the moment the North East of England is suffering with more coronavirus cases, but London and the South are not recording as many.According to experts from the London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine, the East Midlands has the fastest spread of infection with a rate of between . and ..London, which has been the hardest hit in the country has a R rate of . to . - the lowest in the country.Mr Malthouse was asked on Radio s Westminster Hour last nightthat could lead to dferentrates for schools in dferent parts of the country, is that something that could happen And he replied: In theory it could. It’s certainly the reason for us setting up this new bio security centre, as I think was outlined when it was announced, so we can monitor the progress of the virus across the country.Andlocalised action is required, it can be taken,there’s a localised outbreak.What the PM was trying to say was this [schools reopening] is conditional on the numbers going in the right direction.He said it would be helpful to avoid dferences across the country but stressed that scientists were discussing the matter with the unions at the moment to get kids back as soon as its safe to do so.But No said they were not aware of any plans for schools to go back at dferent times.Yesterday Business Secretary Alok Sharma said that regional changes were not on the cards at the moment.Mr Sharma added that it was too soon to discuss a phased lting of lockdown by region.Last week the Prime Ministers spokesperson told reporters that in theory, lockdown rules could be eased at dferent paces across England, but did not specy whether schools would be included.Previously it had been suggested that the lockdown could be tightened again in areas where there was a high infection rate, still.At the moment there are also dferent rules in place between England, Northern Ireland, Scotland and Wales.Rules for seeing one person at a metre distance in an outdoor space only applies in England.And the same goes for unlimited exercise and day trips.Wales and Scotland said they would be not changing any rules yet and wanted to keep people at home for longer.Over the weekend a family trying to drive from England into Wales for a trip were stopped and ordered back home.According to lockdown rules in Wales, people should only leave homeyou have a reasonable excuse to do so.Police in England and Wales have issued over , fines for lockdown breaches during the coronavirus lockdown.Unions and the Government are locked in an ongoing row about whether its safe for kids to go back to school from June  - title: tests for everyone with symptoms matt hancock
story: CORONAVIRUS tests will now be available for anyone aged five and over across the UKthey need it, Matt Hancock has revealed today.The Health Secretary said anyone can apply to have a testthey show signs of having the virus - includingthey lose their sense of taste or smell.Mr Hancock told the House of Commons this afternoon: Everyone aged five and over with symptoms is now eligible for a test.That applies right across the UK across all four nations from now.They can book them online or phone up to get one too, he said.Previously only people over , key workers or their families, were allowed to get one.Anyone who is suffering with a cough, fever or loss of smell would be eligible for the test, from today onwards, he said.This morning a lack of taste and smell were added to the official symptoms of coronavirus.Englands deputy chief medical officer today announced anyone suffering from either will have to self-isolate for seven days and their family remain indoors for .The tests will be available at the drive-in centres across the country, with the army working on mobile testing units to make it easier for those in remote areas.Mr Hancock also revealed that , contact tracers had been hired to help study the spread of the bug and stop it from being transmitted across the country.He told the Commons: Today I can confirm that we have recruited over , contact tracers in England. This includes , health care professionals who will provide our call handlers with expert clinical advice.They will help manually trace the contacts of anyone whos had a positive test and advise them on whether they need to isolate. title: sweden earthquake 4 1 magnitude iron ore mine
story: Thirteen people were in the mine near Kiruna at the time but no one was injured.The mine was quickly evacuated and all work stopped.The quake, north of the Arctic Circle was just below the level of the country’s biggest ever of ., which struck in Sjöbo, south of the country in December .Today’s strike hit the world’s largest underground iron ore mine which is more than a century old.A spokesman for LKAB told Aftonbladet that the water level in the Kiruna mine was rising but pumps were working.He added: When ore is mined, holes and cracks occur which cause great stress . This one happened at , metres below the surface.The Norwegian Seismic Array NORSAR stated the earthquake was tied to the ore extraction activities.The Swedish National Seismic Network said the earthquake shortly after am this morning had a magnitude of ..The Department of Earth Sciences at Uppsala University also measured the quake with a magnitude of ..Björn Lund, a seismologist at Uppsala University, said: Even from an international perspective its a large mine quake.LKAB reported this morning that the quake caused rocks to crash into the mine and that there was still seismic activity at the site.Several people in the city of Kiruna have said that they noticed a severe tremor in the ground.The Swedish state-owned mining company LKAB is the largest iron ore producer in Europe.Swedish officials plan to move the centre of Kiruna two miles to the east for safety reasons under a plan drawn up in .

title: china brings back strict coronavirus lockdown infection spike
story: CHINA has brought back strict coronavirus lockdowns for five million people as two cities are virtually sealed off following a new spike in infections.The news comes as it was revealed Beijing has ordered the mass-testing of millions of citizens to prevent a possible second deadly outbreak.The cities of Jilin and Shulan, both in the northwestern province Jilin, have now been hit with severe clampdowns.Six officials - one from Shulan and five from Jilin - have been removed from their posts following the emergence of local infection clusters, say reports.Shulan, a city with a population of , people, has banned residents from leaving their homes in compounds with confirmed or suspected COVID- cases.Jilin has also sealed off one of its districts after upgrading the areas emergency level to high-risk.The city, with a population of .m, has announced new Wuhan-style lockdown measures and closed schools following a cluster of infections.Officials put Fengman District on high alert after recording more new locally-transmitted cases and at least one additional death.The restrictions include bans on all outbound foot and vehicle traffic, as well as the closure of schools and entertainment venues such as cinemas, gyms and restaurants.Residential districts have been put on closed management, with each household allowed to send one member to shop for essentials once a day.Residents who break the rules will be banned from leaving their homes completely.All shops and the majority of supermarkets were also shut today while city officials are gathering testing kits and protective equipment for health workers.Speaking to CNN, Zhong Nanshan, a respiratory disease expert and adviser to the government, admitted there was a “big challenge” ahead for China.Although the massive county has had a relatively low number of infections, most of the population had not been exposed to the coronavirus and are still susceptible to infection.Last week we reported how China is to test Wuhans  million residents in just  days despite no new domestic cases.It fears a asymptomatic cases, where people show no clinical signs of infection but spread the bug.In other parts of the country, restrictions have been gradually lted.Many in Beijing have been going increasingly mask-less outdoors, although most establishments still require they wear protective gear when indoors among other people and on public transport.China has reported a total of , deaths among , cases of the virus since it was first detected in the central industrial city of Wuhan late last year.Our title: schools uk reopen coronavirus june 1
story: The Government has repeatedly stressed that only when the five tests are met would the lockdown begin to be eased.Officials have instructed schools to get ready for reception, year one and six tofrom the start of June,its safe to still do so.They have issued advice on how to make sure classrooms and playgrounds are as secure as possible - including maximum class sizes of  and keeping desks further apart.Unions and the Government are locked in an ongoing row about whether its safe for kids to go back to school from June  - as Boris Johnson has outlined.Fuming union bosses have ordered their members dont engage with plans, and have put in a string of demands that must be met first.No this afternoon signalled that a final green-light could come as early as this week.Asked when the Government would be able to sayJune  would definitely see the opening of schools to more pupils, a spokesman said: You can see from the discussions that have taken place ... that we are working to seek to resolve this as soon as we can.He didnt challenge claims that the final decision could come this week because next week is half-term.Officials have stressed that nothing will happen before June , and any changes may happen from then onwards.And the Government will publish its scientic advice and SAGE minutes on school safety as soon as possible.Union leader Geoff Barton claimed today that the Government will make the final decision next Thursday - when all the lockdown rules are up for their three-week review.He said: It is also important to understand that the government will only make the final decision on whether to press ahead with the reopening of schools when it reviews the latest science on May , and thatthe evidence does not support this decision at that time, it will be delayed.Cabinet Office minister Michael Gove yesterday said the Government was “confident that children and teachers will be safe” when they doto classrooms.“The clear scientic and clinical advice is that it is safe to have schools reopen, accompanied with social distancing,” he told the BBCs Andrew Marr show.The Governments roadmap gives no specic date on when a decision will be made on any changes.All it says is that changes will be announced at least  hours before coming into effect.It stressed that the five tests set out by Boris Johnson which must be met before any relaxing of the rules.The PM said at the weekend that three of those five have now been met, and progress is being made on the other two.But parents have been promised they will not be punishedthey keep their kids at home.Meanwhile, schools in some areas maybefore others, a minister suggested last night.Policing minister Kit Malthouse was asked about changing lockdown measures dferently across the country - as the rate of spread ies.According to experts from the London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine, the East Midlands has the fastest spread of infection with a rate of between . and ..London, which has been the hardest hit in the country has an R rate of . to . - the lowest in the country.Mr Malthouse was asked on Radio s Westminster Hour last nightthat could lead to dferentrates for schools in dferent parts of the country, is that something that could happen And he replied: In theory it could. title: emerade adrenaline pens recalled allergic reaction
story: Health officials have warned there is a risk some Emerade pens are faulty and have a blockage in the needle.The fault is preventing the devices from delivering the correct dose of adrenaline needed when a patient suffers anaphylaxis.Most of the pens will still activate, but more force may need to be applied, according to the Medicines and Healthcare products Regulatory Agency .Its urging those who carry an Emerade mcg auto-injector to contact their prescriber and seek replacements of an alternative brand.Emerade mcg and mcg have already been recalled - in March and April this year, respectively.The watchdog said it had to carry out the recall in three separate phases to ensure there would be enough supplies of the alternative pens - EpiPen or Jext - to be available for patients.Despite the problem being first spotted in June  during routine testing, the fault was thought to be rare as it involved only . in every , pens.An MHRA spokesperson, said: “Action has been taken to protect patients, following detection of a fault in one component of the Emerade adrenaline auto-injector pens.“Patients shouldall Emerade mcg pens to their local pharmacy once they have a new prescription and have been supplied with pens of an alternative brand.“It is vital that patients follow existing advice to carry two pens with them at all times and to contact their doctor when a replacement is due.“When switching to a dferent brand of adrenaline pen the patient must ensure they are familiar with how to use the pen as each brand is administered dferently.”Healthcare professionals have been advised to contact patients who carry the pens, made by Bausch  Lomb UK Limited, so they can get a prescription for an alternative brand.Patients will then be asked tothem to their local pharmacy where they can collect their new prescription.Alternative brands of adrenaline auto-injector are available in a maximum strength of mcg.But there is data to show that a single EpiPenor Jextpen will be a suitable replacement for a single Emerade mg pen, the MHRA said.Those that need replacement pens are being warned to also follow social distancing advice.The MHRA says that a telephone appointment can be made with a doctor to request a prescription - do not visit your GP surgery in person unless the doctor advises otherwise.Request your prescription is sent to a pharmacy to avoid collecting it in person from the surgery.If you or someone  in your household is self-isolating, ask someone  to collect your prescription or use a home delivery service,available.Once you have the replacement auto-injector pens,Emerade mcg pens to the pharmacy - Some have drop-off boxes to facilitate distancing.The spokesperson added: At present, healthcare professionals are unlikely to be able to help with face to face training but there may be opportunities for remote consultations.Patients must take particular care to read the instructions on how to use the pen which are in the leaflet contained in the box.The manufacturers’ websites for each brand of pen have information and training videos on how to use the auto-injector.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: bella italia cafe rouge jobs
story: BELLA Italia and Cafe Rouge are on the verge of collapse putting , jobs at risk.The owner of both chains, Casual Dining Group, has filed a notice to appoint administrators at the High Court.The company said it will give the chain  days breathing space to consider all options for restructuring.A spokesperson for the chain said: These notications are a prudent measure in light of the companys position and the wider situation.These notications will also protect the company from any threatened potential legal action from landlords while we review the detail of the Government advice, and formulate a plan for the company in these dficult times.The groups  restaurants, which also includes Las Iguanas, have remained closed for the past two months due to lockdown orders even though theyre allowed to operate a takeaway service.It has also furloughed the majority of its staff.It is understood that Casual Dining Group has drafted in advisory firm AlixPartners to consider potential insolvency arrangements or find a way to save the firm.They are reported to be considering a number of possibilities, including company voluntary arrangement , which could see some stores saved.A Casual Dining Group spokeswoman said: As is widely acknowledged, this is an unprecedented situation for our industry and, like many other companies across the UK, the directors of Casual Dining Group are working closely with our advisers as we consider our next steps.The dining-out industry has been hammered by lockdown measures, which has forced millions of non-essential businesses to shut up shop since March.Government plans to reopen cafes, pubs and restaurants have been earmarked for July but this depends greatly on whether the population can dodge a second peak of the virus before then.Even so, food and drink businesses will only be able to reopenthey can enforce strict social distancing measures, which will have an impact on how much profit they can make.So far, restaurant chains Carluccios and Byron have hired insolvency advisers to prepare for permanent closures or to go out of business.Although today, Sky News reports that owners of rival restaurant chain Giraffe, Boparan Restaurants, is said to be about to close a deal to buy Carluccios.The rescue bid would save  jobs at the Italian chain, as well as  out of its  restaurants.Carluccios and administrators FRP have declined to comment.Pubs, cafes and restaurants could be open to sell pints and food as market-style outdoor stalls in just weeks.Ministers are said to be drawing up plans to relax outdoor seating licences as part of measures to get Britain moving again.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: mystery abandoned mansion clothes bentley
story: Once a home anyone would be proud of, the huge property to the north of the city has fallen into disrepair over several years - although it remains eerily well-preserved.And it looks as though its former occupants left hastily, maybe even in the middle of the night.A watch stuck in time lies untouched on a bedside table, while designer clothes bearing the labels Yves St Laurent, Gucci and Louis Vuitton are still stacked up on rails in a bedroom.There are empty fish tanks lined up in a hallway - while a dishwasher stacked with plates waits to be unloaded.However, a clue about the amount of time that has passed since the rooms were occupied can be spotted that part of the kitchen ceiling has caved in.A Japanese-theme piano takes pride of place in one of the rooms with the music left out ready to play, while stacks of china sit on a living room table next to the sofas.A huge bathroom features Jacuzzi-style tub with half-used shampoo and conditioner bottles lined up nearby.Amazingly, a potted plant is still alive on a windowsill next to a telescope lined up ready for its owner to look at the night sky.Bizarrely, a game of chess stands half-finished on the dining room table.A utility room has a snooker table and outside, four or five cars - including a rusted Bentley - lie in overgrown grass.The urban explorer who took the images said he had never seen such a well-preserved house.He said unopened post had filled the entrance hallway.The letters began stacking up in , and he said he assumes the family left the home four years ago.“It was an amazing house to visit,” he said.“I’ve seen a lot of these places and most are in a far worse state than this one.“It was literally like the people who lived there got up in the middle of the night and ran without taking anything.There was dry cleaning still in the plastic wrapping - it appears they didn’t even pack a bag.”He said he believed the former occupants were Russian, but Land Registry documents show the house is owned by a Dorset-based company.“Maybe they fled back to Russia ” he added.“It must have been a fast move as even their toothbrushes were still there.

title: boozing party lockdown garden
story: BOOZING party-goers flouted lockdown rules as at least  pals met for a th birthday bash in a back garden.Footage shows the brazen group dancing, drinking and inhaling balloons as they partied at the home on Saturday night.The clip, believed to have been filmed in the Manchester area, sparked a furious backlash with viewers slamming the group for meeting up during lockdown.One Twitter user wrote: “I actually can’t believe what I’m seeing.“How are people doing this AND posting it all over social media like it’s fine when there’s still  people dying a day    Honestly speechless.”The clip comes as the UK’s coronavirus death toll hit at least , after  more people died in England.One at the party posted it was “still going off” at .pm on Saturday.But their behaviour was slammed online with viewers described those at the party as being “selfish and arrogant”.One wrote: “They just think they’re invisible. It’s people like this that are stopping us from seeing our family – they have no respect.”Another furious viewer added: “Because this age group don’t think they are affected - that they can do what they like, and they are immune.”It comes just days after cops had to break up a street party with a DJ and barbecue during coronavirus lockdown in Nottingham.Officers were called to the out of control party after a number of calls from concerned members of the public.Last week, it emerged police have no powers to enforce social distancing, as senior officers said it would be down to the public to ensure others stuck to the new rules.The latest Government guidance maintains the advice to remain two metres apart when out in public spaces, such as parks.But because social distancing is not part of the coronavirus law, police officers are powerless to keep people apart.Martin Hewitt, chairman of the National Police Chiefs Council, said: Its not for the police to enforce social distancing. Thats guidance, and thats everyones responsibility.Today, NHS England said of the  new deaths, the casualties were aged between  and  years old.Seven of the  patients, who were aged between  and , had no underlying heath conditions.Its the lowest daily total in England since the start of lockdown.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: first coronavirus vaccine tested humans positive results
story: Moderna, a company based in Massachusetts, tested the vaccine on eight people, who all showed an immune response to the virus.It is the first vaccine in the United States to be tested on humans.The volunteers received two doses of the vaccine in March, and made antibodies that were then tested in human cells in a lab.The antibodies were able to stop the virus from replicating.The antibodies produced were similar to those in patients who recovered from a COVID-, the U.S. biotechnology company said in a news release.The vaccine appeared to show a dose response, meaning that people who got higher doses had higher levels of antibodies.Modernas vaccine has received the green light to start the second stage of human testing, and last week, US regulators gave the vaccine fast-track status to speed up the regulatory review.As of May , , people have died in the US from coronavirus.We are investing to scale up manufacturing so we can maximize the number of doses we can produce to help protect as many people as we can from SARS-CoV-, Moderna Chief Executive Officer Stephane Bancel said.Last week, it won the U.S. health agencys fast-track label to speed up the regulatory review. Moderna expects to start a larger late-stage trial in July.The company has signed deals with Swiss contract drugmaker Lonza Group AG and the U.S. government to produce massive quantities of its vaccine.Scientists are still trying to understand what level of antibodies will ultimately prove protective against the novel coronavirus, and how long that protection will last.There are currently no approved treatments or vaccines for COVID-, and experts predict a safe and effective vaccine could take  to  months to develop.The news lted shares of Moderna about % to . in mid-morning trading and drove the broader stock market higher. The vaccine, mRNA-, was also found to be generally safe and well tolerated in the early-stage study, the drug developer said.One person in the trial experienced redness around the injection site, which was characterized as a grade  side effect.No serious side effects had been reported, the company said.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: young women new coronavirus symptom anosmia
story: YOUNG women may be more likely to suffer from the new coronavirus symptom anosmia, experts have discovered.Researchers found that women in their s and  were reporting losing their sense of smell and taste more frequently than others.It comes as the government added a loss of taste or smell to the official NHS coronavirus symptoms list today - weeks after experts first raised concerns that Covid- cases are being missed.Those suffering from anosmia - the clinical name for a loss of smell - will have to self-isolate for seven days, according to new guidance from the UKs chief medical officers.Until now, only Brits with a new fever or persistent cough were told to self-isolate and allowed to get tested.But now those who lose their sense of taste or smell, a noticeable change, can get a coronavirus check.In response to early anecdotal reports of people losing their sense of smell or taste, an international survey was launched.Experts from the Global Consortium for Chemosensory Researchsay they were surprised to find that more women in their s and s were reporting the symptom.Professor Carl Philpott, a smell expert at the University of East Anglia and one of the research members, said: “We are collecting data on Covid- from people in  countries all around the world – and it all points to the fact that smell loss is a symptom.“We have found that it particularly affects some demographics, such as women in their s and s.This is dferent to what we would normally see when people present with anosmia following a virus - that tends to be people who are in an older age group, more commonly in their s and s.“Our research and that from many other centres shows that for some, it can be the only symptom, or accompanied by or precede other mild symptoms.Prof Philpott welcomed the fact the symptom has now been added to the official list but pointed out it was much later than other European counterparts and at least two weeks after the WHO added it to their list.His team hope that people will continue to take part in their survey so they can gather more evidence about the prevalence of the virus in the population.Prof Barry Smith, from the University of London and the UK lead for the GCCR, said: “If enough people are able to tells us about their sudden loss of smell or taste, this will provide vital clues that could be part of the story about the prevalence of the virus in the population – information the Government can all upon before mass antibody testing is available.”Englands deputy chief medical officer, Professor Jonathan Van-Tam, told reporters the move would mean  per cent of cases where people have symptoms are now picked up, a rise from  per cent previously.It comes after a study led by Professor Tim Spector at Kings College London found that  per cent of Covid- positive patients reported loss of smell and taste, compared with only  per cent of those who tested negative for the disease.These results were much stronger in predictingsomebody had coronavirus thanthey reported fever.Speaking about the findings on April , Prof Spector called for the rules to change, saying: When combined with other symptoms, people with loss of smell and taste appear to be three times more likely to have contracted Covid- according to our data, and should therefore self-isolate for seven days to reduce the spread of the disease.On Monday morning, he heavily criticised the Governments stance so far, saying infected people had been encouraged back to work due to a failure to track symptoms properly.He said , to , people in the UK with Covid- were currently not being told to self-isolate even though they had the virus.Prof Spector blamed Public Health Englandand the wider strategy, saying an insistence that only fever and cough were the major symptoms had missed thousands of cases.He added that there are even more symptoms - such as tiredness, stomach pain or diarrhoea - that could be included as possible coronavirus symptoms.The expert said: We list about  symptoms which we know are related to having a positive swab test.These are not being picked up by the NHS. This country is missing them all and not only underestimating cases, but also putting people at risk and continuing the epidemic.Theres no point telling people to be alertthey dont know the symptoms.ENT UK, the professional membership body representing ear, nose and throat surgery in the UK, said it had first warned that loss of smell and taste were symptoms of coronavirus eight weeks ago, saying it had shared those details with PHE.The World Health Organisationlisted loss of smell and taste as less common symptoms several weeks ago and other countries, including the US, added the symptom.Despite these warnings, Prof Van-Tam said on April  that the New and Emerging Respiratory Virus Threats Advisory Grouphad looked at the issue and concluded loss of smell or taste should not be added to the UKs symptom list.But on Monday, that guidance was changed, with Prof Van-Tam saying advisers had needed to look at the issue in detail.He said scientists had had to work out very carefully how valid loss of taste or smell were in counting cases and where in the course of an illness the symptoms might occur. Prof Spectors paper cited loss of smell and taste as being more frequent in people who test positive but very much in the presence of other symptoms, he added.The question for Nervtag has always been: At what point can we be sure that by adding anosmiaor adding anything , frankly - theres plenty of other things such as fatigue, diarrhoea loss of appetite - at what point would adding any of these definitely improve and help us to pick up cases That work has now been completed. And thats why weve got to the position we have now, not just about whether or not anosmia exists - its about what role it plays in identying cases, and thats taken time to work through those data.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: couple lockdown transform garden decking outdoor home cinema
story: Yet this couple can get their film fix after they created a home-made outdoor cinema in their garden in Chesham.Luke Whelan, , and Hannah Ferguson, , converted their garden decking into a cinema at a cost of just £,.They splashed out £, on the wood needed to build the decking, while the projector and screen cost £.The remaining lighting and electrics cost £, which as an electrician, Luke was able to fit himself.Hannah said: The back of our garden is a real sun trap. We wanted to make the most of this and create an outdoor living space.The lockdown has given us the perfect opportunity to create and set up an outdoor cinema to make the most of our time at home and these lovely summer evenings.“We didnt want to spend loads of money on a fancy projector. The one we have is quite basic but it works great once the sun has set. Luke cut a hole into the decking with a flap to conceal a socket in the exact place we need the projector.We utilised an old ‘boom box’ style stereo that we dont use in the house, which gives us the surround sound experience. It simply plugs into the projector and honestly, it’s better than our new fancy sound-bar in the living room.Hannah added: Its amazing to have another living space. We can feel quite cooped upwe spend too long in the house so it’s nice to get cosy with a blanket, a bucket of popcorn, and a hot chocolate outside.It almost feels like were not at home. Weve watched Star Wars, Pirates of the Caribbean, and the Avengers movies – all under the stars. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: meghan markle friend lost touch
story: Pals say Gabriel Stewart, , was left devastated when old high school pal Meghan cut off contact with him after starting on TV show Suits.Disney worker Gabriel, from North Hollywood, who is claimed to have briefly dated the duchess, confirmed to The Sun that he was no longer in contact with the royal.He said: “Meghan and I were close friends, which started in high school, and continued on well after. We always kept in touch, even while she was home sick and working abroad.“But sometimes, as happens, her le took her a dferent direction whatever the reason may be and we lost touch.“I did value our friendship and I am sad to have lost touch with her since I considered us to be close, but that’s fine and I understand it and harbour no ill feelings towards Meghan at all.“She was always a pleasure to be around, sweet to everyone and had lots of good energy. We called her ‘Meghan Markle with a sparkle’.”Meghan, , has been accused of ghosting several people during her rise to fame, including her dad Thomas Sr and Piers Morgan.American reality TV star Nema Vand, , revealed last week how her had “ghosted” his pal ‘Gabe’ after they dated and formed a friendship.Vand, speaking on a US podcast, said: “And by the way,Meghan Markle listens to this, I am going to say this one time. Meghan, you really upset our friend Gabe.“My friend Gabe, that I grew up with, dated Meghan in high school.“He says that after she got on Suits - they were friends for years afterward - he was like: ‘Yeah, she kind of like ghosted me after Suits’.“It really hurt his feelings. I got the sense that Gabe really valued her friendship. So Meghan,you hear this, reach out to Gabe. You know who that is.”Vand, who stars on reality show ‘Shahs of Sunset’, also said that Meghan had “toyed masterfully” with his heart during high school – sitting on his lap and talking to him in Farsi.Meghan is now back living in Los Angeles with Prince Harry, , after the pair quit as frontline royals in March.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes.
