title: groups of six northern ireland
story: GROUPS of up to six people from dferent households will be able to meet outdoors in Northern Ireland from tomorrow.The new rules come as ministers agree to ease coronavirus lockdown restrictions - as long as social distancing measures are followed.It means families in Northern Ireland will be able to meet up outdoorsthey keep their distance - something which is forbidden in the rest of the UK.Garden centres and recycling centres have already reopened in Northern Ireland and today, Stormont First Minister Arlene Foster confirmed that places of worship would also reopen for inidual prayer.Drive-in religious services, cinemas, concerts and live theatre would also be permitted allowed, as long as audiences stay in their cars.However, people are still not allowed to visit family members from other households indoors, even though it is included in step one of Northern Irelands recovery.First Minister Arlene Foster said she understood that would be disappointing for some people, but gave a commitment to constantly review the measures.She said: We would have liked to unlock the whole of step one but, quite simply, the reason why we havent been able to move to indoor family gatherings is because of the medical advice.The relaxations weve announced have been made made possible by the vast majority of you following advice.They have been hard-won freedoms and its vital when you exercise them, it doesnt put anyone s safety at risk.Deputy First Minister Michelle ONeill urged people in Northern Ireland to Bear with us, adding that as soon as the advice changed, the Executive would move to lt that restriction.She said: We will get there and well get there sooner,we all keep doing what were doing.Last week, the Executive published its five-phase blueprint for recovery in Northern Ireland, but it does not have a timetable.Coronavirus lockdown rules dfer in England, Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland.Prime Minister Boris Johnson announced a lting of some restrictions during a televised address on Sunday, May , but these do not apply to the whole of the United Kingdom and British Isles.The lockdown was extended in Northern Ireland by another three weeks last week.Ms Foster however said at the time that there would be nuanced tweaks to the rules in the days ahead.She said: On the whole, the message is to stay at home.“We will say we are not deviating from the message at this time.“It is important for people to know we are not doing this in a nanny state way. Once we can move, we will move.”To receive The Suns Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.

title: uk weather forecast hottest day of the year
story: THE UK is set to bask in the hottest day of the year so far as temperatures are predicted to rise as high as Cthis week.It comes as Brits are now allowed to sunbathe in parks and exercise outdoors even more than once a day under relaxed lockdown measures.Over the next few days, most parts of the UK will see warm sunshine and clear skies.On Wednesday, the temperature in London and the south-east of England could surpass C .Parts of the UK will be warmer than some of Europes top holiday destinations, including Marbella and Ibiza.The mini heatwave will continue into Friday, testing the nations determination as people are asked to avoid crowded outdoor spaces and observe the two-metre social distancing.Met Office meteorologist Matthew Box said there will be a north-south ide on Monday and Tuesday - with some rain in north-western parts of the UK, while southern areas will reach highs of C .In the middle of the week, warm winds from the Mediterranean are set to start moving north.By Wednesday, parts of Scotland and northern Ireland will reach highs of Cwhile Wales could see Cby the afternoon.The North of England will hit a maximum temperature of C .Mr Box said: Its going to be very hot for large parts of England for most of the week, reaching highs of Con Wednesday, which would make it the hottest day of the year so far.This will occur due to large areas of high pressure, combined with southerly winds from the continent, bringing with it, pleasant sunshine, dry skies and warmer air.There is a possibility of thunder and rain across the south and east of England and Wales on Thursday.Friday could be windy, mainly for western areas, with heavy downpours.Under new Government guidelines, Brits can now travel anywhere in England by car with members of their own household - so long as theyon the same day.The new measures, which came into effect last Wednesday, also allow Brits to meet one person from a dferent household - but always keeping two metres apart.It is also possible to picnic outside, for example at parks or beaches.When the new guidelines were introduced, Prime Minister Boris Johnson urged people to continue keeping a safe social distance from others.He said: We want to encourage people to take more and even unlimited amounts of outdoor exercise.You can sit in the sun in your local park, you can drive to other destinations, you can even play sports but only with members of your own household.But he warned: You must obey the rules on social distancing and to enforce those rules we will increase the fines for the small minority who break them.Mr Johnson also thanked the public for following the lockdown guidelines.He said: It is thanks to your effort and sacrice in stopping the spread of this disease that the death rate is coming down and hospital admissions are coming down.Thanks to you we have protected our NHS and saved many thousands of lives.

title: coronavirus several years autumn winter return
story: BRITS have been warned to learn to live with coronavirus for several years and prepare for a possible second wave of the bug. Englands deputy chief medical officer Professor Jonathan Van-Tam today warned the country will only be out of this once a vaccine has been found - and that Covid- mayagain in autumn and winter.Speaking during todays coronavirus briefing, Prof Van-Tam said it would take a vaccine really capable of suppressing disease levels for the country to be out of this.He added: So from that perspective we may have to live, and learn to live, with this virus in the long-term, certainly for many months to comenot several years.Prof Van-Tam said further information is needed on the seasonality of Covid-,He said: One of the things thats very clear with flu viruses is that they come in our cold winters and the levels of transmission and circulation decline over the summer months.The data we have on other coronaviruses we have looked at very carefully, and its not clear that these coronaviruses are as seasonal as influenza.But there may be an element of seasonality and it may well be that the autumn and winter conditions provide a better environment for the virus to then do its work again.Despite fears we may never find a vaccine, one manufacturer has said its coronavirus jab has been tested on humans and appears to show positive results.Moderna, a company based in Massachusetts, tested the vaccine on eight people, who all showed an immune response against the virus.Meanwhile, it has emerged that the Ebola drug remdesivir is set to be approved to treat patients with the bug in Europe within days.The World Health Organisationpreviously dubbed it the most promising treatment for Covid- among all the other medicines being studied in trials.It comes after the Health Secretary announced coronavirus tests would be made available to anyone in the UK aged five or over,they need it.Matt Hancock said anyone can apply to have a testthey show signs of having the virus - includingthey lose their sense of taste or smell.

title: union teachers unsafe marking books coronavirus
story: HARD-LINE unions have claimed it is “not safe” for teachers to mark children’s books during the pandemic.They are calling for headteachers to abolish marking altogether during the crisis.And they want a ban on books being taken from school back to kids’ homes after class.All library books should be “regularly sanitised”, unions say.And teachers should be told to wash their hands after handling books, they demanded.The health and safety demands are part of a detailed -step check list they say must be met before schools reopen.Former Tory leader Iain Duncan Smith branded the demands “ludicrous”.He fumed: “It beggars belief they are saying this.“These teachers are buying food from the shops. There is a greater risk there than there is marking kids’ work.”Ministers will make their final decision on whether to gradually reopen schools as planned on June  when they assess the lockdown next Thursday.The Sun understands schools in parts of England could be allowed to delay their reopening — but onlycoronavirus rates of infection have shot up locally.But four unions — the NEU, GMB, Unison and Unite — have ramped up their opposition.Their -step document tells union reps they should only agree to schools reopening more fullyevery demand is met.And they warn that evenevery single concern is dealt with, they still expect to oppose plans to gradually reopen schools from June .The document states: “It seems extremely unlikely at present that circumstances nationally will permit that.”They demand that teachers are allowed to wear masks and PPE — even though Public Health England says this would usually not be needed.And entire schools should closestaffing levels drop, the document says.Kevin Courtney, of the NEU, defended his -page check list.He said: “The checklist is detailed because there are so many considerations to take into account when dealing with a school situation, particularly as we are looking at our youngest children going back first.“Parents would expect nothing less.”Tory MP Robert Halfon, chairman of the education select committee, said unions should be “as concerned about the risk to many thousands of vulnerable children” of not being educated.Evidence shows kids are not as vulnerable to Covid-.The virus can live on paper for ying s of time, but government advice is to wash hands rather than avoid books.Professor Matthew Snape, from Oxford University, said “only a very small number of children” get sick from Covid-.He said: “Also, it seems the children who get Covid- do not become ‘super-spreaders’, unlike what we see in viruses such as influenza.”A Department for Education spokesman said: “We want children back in schools as soon as possible because being back with their teachers and friends is so important for their education and their well-being.”The reopening of schools in  European countries has not led to a signicant increase in coronavirus infections, EU education bosses said today.Blaženka Divjak, Croatia’s education minister, said: “So far we haven’t heard anything negative about the reopening of schools, but it is probably too early to have final conclusions.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: premier league june free
story: Culture Secretary Oliver Dowden today confirmed the Government were desperate to bring football backit could be done safely.Appearing on Sky News, the minister claimed making games free to watch was important to give people something to watch at home.He said: “We are working hard with them to try and get it back, I am aiming for mid-June.“The number one test is public safety.Im hoping that we can have something a bit more ambitious with some more free-to-air matches available so people can watch from home because that would be helpful in terms of discouraging people from leaving their homes.“What we are aiming for is to finish the season from behind close doors from mid June onwards.”All  clubs will meet today, with a vote to take place on the new training protocols.At least  of them need to back the new criteria, which includes getting changed at home for training and driving to ground on their own.Earlier this month, Boris Johnsons Government gave the green light to elite-level sport behind closed doors from June .Health officials have remained in close contact with football bosses as they draw up plans to bring players and staff back to training before matches can resume.It comes after Germany’s top league the Bundesliga ed at the weekend behind closed doors.Games took place at empty stadiums with a limited number of people present and measures such as substitutes sitting two metres apart and wearing masks.This morning Watford Captain Troy Deeney questioned how prepared the Government were.He said: “The concern that stages two and three have not been clearly laid out.“Government guidelines are saying that its four times more likely for people of colour to get the illness and twice as likely to have lasting illnesses but theres no extra screening, theres no additional checks being done on any players because it costs too much money.Simple things like that are where people are asking questions and its not being answered.When people cant answer the questions, you start to panic and start to worry.Meanwhile the British Medical Association has launched an attack on the Premier League for buying up so much PPE – as NHS workers battle the coronavirus on the frontline.A BMA spokesman said: “The latest BMA survey results seem to show the supply chain situation is improving but there are still issues in some areas.“It is important that these are resolved first, and adequate and consistent supply is available across the health service, before we consider non-essential sectors.”It comes as it emerged pubs cafes and restaurants could be open to sell pints and food as market-style outdoor stalls in just weeks.Ministers are drawing up plans to relax outdoor seating licences as part of measures to get Britain moving again.Next month marks the earliest possible time the second stage of the Governments three step plan to reopen Britain can get underway.Many hospitality venues have been completely closed since the Prime Minister Boris Johnson announced a full lockdown back in March.It is hoped the outdoor openings will allow businesses to get people back to work.

Health Secretary Matt Hancock set out plans for easier, faster and simpler testing so more people can access a Covid- test to tellthey currently have the virus. Wider testing will be essential before the government can ease up properly on the UK lockdown - because itaposll show whether the virus is running rampant again. Mr Hancock told the House of Commons on May : Everyone aged  and over with symptoms is now eligible for a test. That applies right across the UK in all four nations from now. It was the latest expansion in eligibility, three weeks after testing was extended to over-s or people who need to leave home for work, with symptoms.The Health Secretary added: Our ultimate goal is that everyone who could benefit from a test gets a test. But you may have to drive for a -minute round trip to get a test and there has been heavy demand on new kits posted to your home. Meanwhile, critics have slammed the slow rollout of testing to the wider community after it was initially ditched due to lack of capacity in March. Hereaposs who is eligible and how the system will work. Who is eligible for a test   As the UK extends its testing capacity a growing list of people are eligible to be tested:All those in the UK who have symptoms and are over five years old in the UK All those working on the frontline in health and social care * Patients in the NHS and residents in care homes **But thereaposs a catch... What about care homes  More than a third of all the nationaposs care homes have had an outbreak after repeated failings to take tests early in the pandemic. Staff and residents were not routinely able to have a coronavirus test until April . And nor were patients coming into care homes from hospitals routinely tested until that date. The governmentaposs guidance now says care home residents and staff can be tested, with or without symptoms. But the governmentaposs roadmap for easing lockdown says this is only expected to roll out fully by June . How sick do you have to be   You need to show symptoms in order to be tested, unless you are in a care home of the NHS. The three main symptoms are a new and persistent dry cough a temperature and changes to your sense of taste or smell.    It will showyou currently have Covid-. This is useful to proveyour symptoms are actually the virus. It does not showyouaposve had Covid- in the past. It will help people work out when they and their household members canto work safely. Where do I log on to book a test  Visit the governmentaposs web page. Slots for home testing kits tend to appear at am and can be snapped up quickly. Where do I go to get tested     The first port of call is a drive-through testing centre. The government expects you to be able to drive for up to  minutes from your home to get to a drive-through site, leaving some with potentially a -minute round trip. WhatI canapost drive   For those who donapost live near enough to a testing site or canapost drive there are other options. Home testing kits have been available since late April. The availability of these was limited at first, with , selling out within two minutes on the first day. What about other ways of getting tested  Meanwhile apossatelliteapos test kits are also being sent directly to care homes to enable residents with symptoms to be tested. And the Army is helping set up mobile testing units which travel the country to places like care homes, police stations and prisons. How long will I wait for results     The government claims test results are being turned around and sent out within  hours, or  hours for home testing kits after you send the sample off. Test results come by text message. But many have reported longer waits for tests to come back. Why were essential workers getting tested first  The aim was simple - to ensure they can get back to work. Because the test showsyou currently have Covid-, it also can given an indication that your cough is just a  alarm. Primary schools in England are meant to reopen from June , starting with Years R,  and . But unions and some whole cities are staging a revolt, warning there is not yet enough evidence that itaposs safe. The key questions are whether children are infected like adults are whether they then spread the virus to others and whether theyaposre less likely to get seriously ill and die. The science is still evolving, and papers from the governmentaposs scientic advisors are expected to be published in the coming days. But we do already have some hints about what the evidence shows. These have come in several forms, but here in England weaposve had two very helpful updates in recent days. They are an overview of scientic advice from the Department for Education, and an update from Englandaposs Deputy Chief Medical Officer, Prof Jonathan Van Tam. They both say children could be as likely to get infected as adults but that when they are infected, theyaposre much less likely to get sick. The key question for reopening schools, though, is how much children transmit the virus to others - and hereaposs also where the evidence is hazy. Here is what Prof Jonathan Van Tam and the Department for Education have said. Can children become infected with coronavirus  Yes.Government scientists believe younger children - aged up to  or  - might be less susceptible to getting infected with coronavirus.But they warn the “degree of confidence is low” - meaning they can’t be sure one way or the other. Prof Van Tam said emerging data suggests the rate at which children become infected is “about the same as in adults, possibility a little lower in the younger children”. Is coronavirus as serious in children as adults  No. When children get Covid- it’s usually a “much more mild” disease than in adults, Prof Van Tam said. It is pretty well established thatthey get coronavirus, young children are far less at risk of falling very ill or having to go to hospital. Medical experts believe up to  children in the UK have been affected from a condition similar to Kawasaki disease, which has been linked to coronavirus. However, the exact nature of any link is still being investigated and Prof Van Tam said we are talking about “very very very small numbers” of children.  How much do children transmit coronavirus to adults  Some studies suggest younger children may transmit the virus less than adults. But this evidence is mixed and provides a low degree of confidence at best”, the government says. Englandaposs deputy chief medical officer Professor Jonathan Van-Tam added the data is pretty sparse at the moment”.

title: seven ways travel safer you
story: NewsSeven ways to travel saferyou need to use public transport during the lockdownAnyone who needs to take public transport should wear face masks, keep their distance from fellow travellers and avoid rush hourpossible, the Department for Transport has said - here is how you can stay safeShareCommentsByOliver MilnePolitical Correspondent:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY NewsIf you can social distance then you should " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailPassengers on public transport are unlikely to be able to practice social distancing safely, the government has admitted. Police were out in force on Monday as the operators stepped up services as lockdown measures ease slightly. The Rail Delivery Group said services this week will increase from about % of the standard timetable to %. However, capacity will be reduced to as little as % of normal levels to ensure social distancing, while passengers are being urged to avoid non-essential travel. But publishing guidance for both passengers and operators the Department for Transport warned that “there will be times and some settings on public transport where social distancing is not possible”. But with the Government calling on those who cannot work from home in certain industries toto work from tomorrow, it is inevitable that more people will be getting public transport. So here is the governmentaposs advice to make sure you can make any trip you have to take as safe as possible. Do not travelyouaposre unwell or clinically extremely vulnerable People have been asked not to take any non-essential travel by public transport, but evenyour trip is essential you shouldnapost take ityou have any coronavirus symptoms or are part of the vulnerable groups, people with underlying conditions, who the Government have urged to shield themselves. If youaposre self-isolating you should also, obviously, avoid public transport Check ahead and travel when quieter Even as public transport routes begin to step up activity, there is still likely to be disruption to the nornal arrangements, so the government is asking people to plan a head by identying alternative routes and options in case of unexpected disruption. They also suggest thatcan, travel at off-peak times, and you should ask your employer to consider letting you start late or leave early to avoid peaks.  Buy tickets ahead of timeOn some services you will now now required to book ahead of time. If you are travelling on  LNER trains then you need to know that is ‘reservation only’ travel from  May Passengers will have to reserve their seat orthey are using a flexible ticket such as a season ticket, they can avail the online seat reservation tool or speak to staff. Passengers who have an existing reservation should choose a seat at a distance and ignore the seat details. On other networks it has been recomended that where possible, that you book your travel online through your transport provider’s ticketing app or website. Some networks - like Nothern Rail - have said that the layout and frequency of trains might in order to ensure social distancing.So you must check the timetable ahead of time - and where possible just pick up your ticket in advance. Consider contactless payment to buy tickets. Try and keep social distance If you can take a less busy route, you should try and obviously where possible you should keep metres away from people. But where that isnapost possible the advice is to keep the time you spend nears others as short as possible and avoid physical contact. It adds: Be aware of the surfaces you touch. Be careful not to touch your face. Cover your mouth and nose with a tissue or your elbow when coughing or sneezing. To avoid crowds it suggests you try to start or end your journey using a station or mode of transport you know to be quieter or more direct. For instance, walk the first or last mile of your journey, or alight at an earlier station, where this is possible.  Wear a face covering and travel lightly While the guidance stresses that wearing a face covering is not a legal requirement it stresses thatyou can wear one while on public transport you should. And it suggests making a list of items that you need to take with you in order to minimise the luggage you take. Also, the advice suggests you donapost eat or drink on public transport. Pay attention to the safety instructions around you and follow basic travel ettiquette Operators have been told they must set out schemes to try and make travelling more secure and this will mean restrictions on where you stand or how to queue. It goes without saying that you should follow these. It may mean going into or out of a dferent entrance or only boarding from a particular part of the train or bus.

story: NewsSingle mum-of-four launches legal fight after shes denied a Covid benefit boostThe DWPs perverse rules mean a single mum has ended up £ a month worse off - despite Universal Credit rising by £ a week during coronavirusShareCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY NewsThe unnamed woman has bizarrely found herself worse off due to the coronavirus benefit boost" to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid Email A single mother-of-four has launched a legal battle against the government after she was denied a boost to benefits due to coronavirus. The unnamed woman should have been one of millions to benefit from a temporary £-a-week increase to Universal Credit, starting in April. But lawyers say she is £.-a-monthworseoff - because while repayments for her advances have risen, her actual welfare cash has been limited by the annual benefit cap.The woman, who has written a pre-action letter, the first stage of a legal action, could be one of thousands in the same situation. The single mum lives in a small two-bedroom house with her children aged , six, three and one. She said she was only having to repay advances because she fell victim to fraud. Now my children and I are suffering, she said in a statement through her lawyers. The changes to benefits in the pandemic have left me worse off when they were supposed to help me during this dficult time. How can that be right  She added: I have had to face extra costs because my -year-old and six-year-old aren’t in school. I am struggling to home-school them. I just want to receive the additional help other Universal Credit claimants are being given.”  The benefit cap affects , households - more than two-thirds of them single parents. The flagship Tory policy limits total annual benefits to £, or £, in London. Critics it creates apossocial cleansingapos by forcing families out of expensive areas with high rents.  The womanaposs lawyers Leigh Day argue the decision to keep applying the benefit cap and advance payment deductions is irrational and perverse. The legal firm say the policy violates her right to a family le under the European Convention on Human Rights .  And the case argues she has suffered unjustied discrimination because most of those hit by the benefit cap are single parents. DWP officials said for most people, the £-a-week rise in Universal Credit will absorb deductions for things like advances. Claimants can also claim free school meal vouchers, have a nine-month grace period where UC is not cappedthey have a sustained work record, and ask for repayments to be delayed for three months.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA third council in England is set to defy government advice to reopen schools next month  - saying that the risk to pupils and staff is unacceptable. Bury in Greater Manchester has now joined Hartlepool and Liverpool as they reject plans to allow teachers and childrento the classroom on June . The council has now written to all headteachers in the area outlining the reasons behind their decision.The statement claimed the reopening classrooms would “pose an unacceptable risk to pupils, staff and communities of vulnerable people.” Labour councillor for Bury Tamoor Tariq said on Twitter that the governmentaposs position is ill advised and not one we can follow.Liverpool Mayor Joe Anderson warned last week that he would resist sending kids back at the beginning of next month, saying he had concerns about whether schools would be able to operate safely. He told BBC Newsnight: “I’m not going to take risks with children’s lives or with staff and teaching professionalsapos lives.” While leaders in Hartlepool said it they would be taking a measured and cautious approach to this.Last weekend, senior minister Michael Gove told parents it was safe to send their kids back to school - but confusingly added aposthere would be risksapos.He told the BBC’s Andrew Marr: “It is absolutely safe,” then said the only way to be sure was to “stay at home” as there is “always, always... a risk”. Teaching unions fear it is unsafe for pupils and staff to go back to school on June . And Labour wants the test and trace system to be put in place before schools .  Mr Gove told BBC’s The Andrew Marr Show: Yes, teachers will be safe in schools... Some of the best leaders in current education have said that it is absolutely safe for children to , absolutely safe for teachers and other staff toas well.But askedhe could guarantee no teacher would be infected as a result of ing to the classroom, he said: The only way ever to ensure that you never catch coronavirus is to stay at home completely.There is always, in any loosening of these restrictions, a risk of people catching coronavirus. You can never eliminate risk, but... it’s extremely unlikely any school is likely to be the source of a Covid outbreak, andfor any reason there are risks we can take steps to mitigate them. Universities aposcould rush to reopen campusesapos Universities could rush to reopen campuses when it is still unsafe to do so amid increased competition to attract students, MPs have been told. Jo Grady, general secretary of the University and College Union , warned that leaving the decision to institutions could be dangerous as financial pressures could encourage them to reopen prematurely. The Office for Students , the higher education regulator, has urged universities not to make any promises to students that everything will be back to normal in the autumn termthis is not the case.

title: uks coronavirus track trace app
story: NewsUKs coronavirus track and trace app delayed despite Government promising mid-May launchIt casts doubt on Downing Streets plan to ease lockdown, which has tracking and tracing the spread of Covid- at its coreShareByOliver MilnePolitical Correspondent:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY NewsThe NHS apps UK wide roll out may have been delayed again " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThe launch of the UKaposs track and trace app appears to have been delayed, with Downing Street now saying that the nationwide rollout will happen within weeks. Speaking at the Downing Street press conference Dominic Raab confirmed the delay, but said it wouldnapost necessarily delay lting lockdown measures. He said: “All of these steps are a balanced assessment, not just of one or other element, but particularly the R level and the prevalence of coronavirus. “It’s still our intention to roll it out across the country for everyone to use in the weeks ahead. I can’t be any more precise at this stage The app, which is central to the governmentaposs programme for containing the virus while lockdown eases, was originally due to launch by mid-May, according to previous comments by Health Secretary Matt Hancock. But Boris Johnsonaposs official spokesman today said that the app would now be coming within weeks. It is currently being tested by people on the Isle of Wight, where the number of sign-ups is supposed to have exceeded expectations. The development of the app has also been fraught with technical issues, with previous designs struggling to overcome some limitations imposed on the app by phone manufacturers and operating systems. Last week Mr Hancock said the target for roll out was mid may in a conversation with Sky News. The Health Secretary said: “We’re rolling out in mid-May. The Isle of Wight project has gone well so far, we’ve learned a lot about how the app operates, also about people who don’t have the app – how to make sure that they can get testing and the contact tracing can work for them – the interaction of the technology and the human-based contact tracing. “We’re pleased with progress, and we’re going to bring it in. And we’re going to learn the lessons from the technical improvements that we’re making from what we’ve seen on the Isle of Wight.” On Monday No insisted that while the app would play an important roll in the future of the track and trace regime, it was possible to do track and tracing work separately to the app. It comes as Mr Hancock confirmed that , contract tracers have been hired.  At the weekend the figure was ,, and Hancock had set himself a target of , by this week. Mr Hancock says the , include , healthcare professionals, who will lead on particularly dangerous clusters, like those in care homes. The trainers have been given rigorous training and were praised by Mr Hancock for stepping up to serve their country in its hours of need.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailTheir friends will look the same, their teachersapos faces familiar and their lessons will continue - but Britain’s primary pupils face an alien landscape when theyto the classroom. The artwork that once adorned the walls will have been torn down, their desks spaced two metres apart and toys, Lego blocks and even old fashioned counting beads will have disappeared. Lunchtimes will be spent at desks, outside play equipment cordoned off, toilet times will be scheduled and contact with teachers so limited that they won’t even be able to put a plaster on a child who falls over. This will be the sterile reality of le in the UK’s , primaries when they open in June. And teachers fear it will have a huge emotional impact on kids.  One East Yorkshire teacher said: “We are worried how this will affect children’s mental health and also educational outcomes. “I’m concerned that parents are not being made aware of what education will look like and that their child’s experience will be far from normal. “Children have already undergone a lot of disruption and, at a time when we wish we couldto our normal routines in order to reassure them, I fear this will only unsettle them further.” Health Secretary Gavin Williamson has left it to inidual schools to have “flexibility” to follow Government guidelines, which mirror the approach of schools in Denmark which started a phasedin April. Head teachers now face the headache of making their schools safe for reception and Year One and Six primary classes and in just two weeks. The guidelines suggest schools introduce one-way systems for kids, ide corridors to keep them apart and stagger breaks as well as arrival and home times so parents don’t congregate. It’s also advised youngsters are placed into small gangs of friends who will not be allowed to mix with other sets or dferent years. Constant hand-washing will be in place when kids arrive, come in from play and before and after eating. The guidelines state: “Consider how to encourage young children to learn and practice these habits through games, songs and repetition.” One head teacher this week took the unusual move of spelling out the changes to parents on her school website, writing: “Some of the parents who want their child tohave stated this is for their mental health and well-being. “This worries me more as I do feel some of the measures I will have to take will completely work against this.”  In a list of changes, headed ‘The Truths’, headteacher Marianne Allan, of Cambois Primary School in Blyth, Northumberland, told parents that all unnecessary furniture and equipment will be removed, teachers will not be allowed to sit beside pupils who need help and lunches will be eaten in classrooms. Ms Allan said children who fall over or have a toilet accident will be encouraged to change themselves or clean their scrape or cut. Otherwise parents will have to collect them. In a poignant message she wrote: “Today I looked at a memory on my phone. It was from a year ago today when some girls in year  and  made me the most beautul table for my lunch, it was covered in lip gloss to smell nice and full of sparkle and jewels. “This is the school I miss. These are the activities we hope to resume. “This will NOT be possible in June. This is the school we want to see back, where children run up and hug their teachers and friends. The school children can walk safely around a building without measures or go to the toilet without supervision and for them to be cleaned afterwards.”  The Government has prioritised reception and Year one learners because they are learning “basic essentials” and Year Six so they can prepare for the move to High School. In Secondaries, Year  and  will get some “face-to-face” time with teachers. But one primary teacher in Bridlington said: “The classrooms will be striped bare of any joy. “Art work will be banned from the wall, resources like counting bricks and beads will be banned to stop the spread of the virus. “Our school has made the decision not to mark exercise books for  hours just to be safe. “it’s so sad because there will be no toys for the little ones in reception and we won’t even be able to help them take bottle lids off their juicethey struggle. “I don’t say this to make parents feel guilty because I know some have no choice but to send their children, but they have a right to know what the reality will be.”

Horried Daisy Pike from Enfield, London, purchased the £. chicken to eat yesterday, but instead found the unusual mass. The -year-old filmed her friend Danielle Jones, as she cut into the foul-smelling lump, which she described as an abscess. As the clip begins, Danielle is seen rinsing the meat under a tap, as she handles the lump, she immediately begins to gag. She then squeezes the bulge which begins to emit a green, pus-like substance. She shrieks: Did you see that blood  That is a dirty abscess, what the f*** is going on  Danielle then decides to cut off the lump and Daisyaposs horried four-year-old asks: What the hell is that  The -year-old squashes the mass with the scissors and more white fluid oozes out. She replies: That is disgusting and heaving again, adds that it is all pus.  Daisy zooms in on the fleshy growth and says: That is absolutely rank. More fluid continues to stream out, causing the group to start retching again. A horried Daisy took to social media to warn others about the meat.  She posted the videos with the caption: Look at this please. This is why you should always check your meat. Aldi Enfield Retail Park, chicken full of puss, had a puss sack and all sorts. Disgusted ainapost the word. Be careful guys. Daisyaposs post has sickened social media users.  Lia McCarthy wrote: I canapost even watch this, look how grim. Patricia Jones added: I have never seen anything like that from meat I have brought from anywhere. And Lisa Arnold said: Omg! That literally made me nearly vomit. Speaking today, bartender Daisy said: It smelt really bad, the lump felt exactly like it wouldit was an abscess on a human.  I ran to the toilet and physically had to be sick, and my friend as you can hear, she was truly disgusted. Even my four-year-old daughter was heaving. What makes it worse is I usually get universal credit, so due to not being at work Iaposve been given meal vouchers and this is where I chose to spend them.

Lancashire Police have released pictures of the light green Toyota Avensis in the hope of finding those responsible for her killing. Aya was reportedly gunned down from a car window while walking to Lidl just  metres from her home in Blackburn, Lancashire, yesterday. The aposappalling and senselessapos daylight shooting has left the local community in shock and her family aposutterly distraughtapos, police say. DCC Terry Woods, of Lancashire Police, said: “We believe a green-coloured Toyota Avensis was used to commit the offence, and this car was later recovered nearby. If you saw the car in the area of King Street and Whalley Banks, oryou saw it being abandoned on Wellington Road, again we would urge you to get in touch. Similarlyyou have information about who had been using this vehicle either on the day of the attack or in the weeks preceding, please tell us. Police say Aya was killed after a light green Toyota Avensis with numerous people inside drove past her. Bullets were fired from the vehicle, with one of them hitting the teen. Officers later found a Toyota Avensis with the registration SV UBP.  DCC Woods added: This was an appalling and senseless attack on an innocent young woman, whose le was cut short while she was simply out doing some shopping. “First and foremost our condolences are with her family, who have lost their daughter during the holy month of Ramadan. “In the last  hours we have learnt that Aya was a much-loved family member and friend who was enjoying her studies at the University of Salford. She also gave her time to being a young trustee of the Children’s Society. For her le to have been cut short like this is unthinkable and her family are understandably utterly distraught. He appealed for anyone in the King Street and Whalley Banks areas of Blackburn around the time of the killing to contact police. Ayaaposs family said:Our beautul -year-old daughter Aya has been taken from us in the most horric circumstances.She was the most loyal devoted daughter who enjoyed spending time with her family especially her brothers and sisters Ibraham, Assil and Amir. She excelled in her studies both at Blackburn Central High School and at Salford University where she was in her second year and dreamed of becoming a solicitor. She had just completed her exams and was learning to drive.

title: darren lewis need coronavirus action
story: NewsopinionDarren Lewis: Coronavirus has shown me the weigh to surviveCovid- is killing more men than women, according to the World Health Organisation, and those with a wider waistline even more so. Its time for me to get the weight offShareCommentsByDarren Lewis:,  MAY NewsopinionLosing weight could save me " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailIt is time for me to save my le. Dramatic  Maybe.It is hardly the moment of clarity that shocks alcoholics or gamblers into surrendering to a higher power. But it is a realisation thatI’m not to become a coronavirus statistic I need to lose weight. Especially with a new survey revealing nearly half the country has put on around lb a week during lockdown. Covid- is killing more men than women, according to the World Health Organisation. Those with a wider waistline even more so. It is also killing twice as many black men and women than white. Factor in my age – forty- – and I’m probably in the position of unspoken pressure that many black and Asian public sector workers find themselves.As a football reporter I need to go back out to work. The Premier League is set to restart next month. But I’m concerned – I can’t lie.I know that the feeling will be: If everyone  is back, why can’t you be  Yet how can I not be apprehensive after two months of widespread death in BAME households Or after seeing my younger sister suffer from the Covid- symptoms  I can’t stay at home forever. I know that. But I can ensure, medically, that I am not vulnerable to a disease which kills by attacking lung tissue. If, like me, you weigh more than you should then your lungs will be constricted already, simply through force of compression.Andyou tend to be chronically out of breath anyway, then good luck. To be fair, I’ve lost a stone already. The turning point came when Boris Johnson went into intensive care.At the time they reckoned he weighed st lb – too much considering he stood at ft in. He believes cycling to work, keeping him relatively  fit, saved his le.

title: homeowners say diy during lockdown
story: NewsHomeowners say DIY during lockdown is leaving them calm and stress-freeA study of , adults has found that a lack of motivation, time and confidence were among the biggest barriers to completing improvements on their homesShareCommentsByAlice Hughes:,  MAY NewsHomeowners have been undertaking DIY projects during the coronavirus lockdown" to FREE email alerts from Mirror - daily newsSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailHomeowners are turning to DIY to improve their wellbeing - saying it leaves them feeling relaxed, calmer and even stress-free. A study of , adults revealed almost three-quarters enjoy the mental boost they get from completing home improvements. One in  are left feeling less stressed, while % are aposcalmerapos after nailing a DIY task in their home. And two in five feel apossatisfiedapos after a spot of DIY, with almost a fth going as far as to say they feel aposrelaxedapos. It also emerged the lockdown has been a driver for many to tackle jobs around the home, as being there more than ever means they now notice what needs doing. But % admitted they had no idea just how much work there was to do. The research, commissioned by Ronseal, found doing DIY has helped more than two thirds combat boredom, while another one in three said it means they will have something to show for their time. Painting has been the most popular task over the last few weeks, with % giving their walls a fresh lick of paint, % sprucing their fences up and % getting their brushes out on the garden furniture. A further one in six have filled in wall cracks and one in  have upcycled furniture. Rob Green, from Ronseal, said: A lack of time and knowledge can make DIY a daunting prospect, and as a result, many simply put off the little jobs that need doing, even though most will be a simple fix. But after a while, you become so used to seeing the problems around the home that you donapost even notice them anymore - especially when you are busy going in and out all of the time. This is changing now we are all spending so much more time at home. When you are at home  , it becomes much harder to turn a blind eye to that bit of scuffed paintwork or the cracks in the walls you are now spending so much time looking at.  The study also found more than halfhave cracked on with DIY during lockdown, with an average of four jobs being completed - although they also have four tasks outstanding. Usually, DIY jobs are ignored for an average of eight weeks before finally being tackled, with a quarter admitting they caused more damage by leaving it untouched. Before lockdown, a lack of motivation , timeand confidencewere among the biggest barriers to completing home improvements. But % of those polled, via OnePoll, admitted they now have aposno excuseapos not to crack on with the jobs.  The study, by Ronseal which is partnered with the UK Menaposs Sheds Association, found that as well as being able to tick it off their to-do list, % said staying on top of DIY is good for their wellbeing. The UK Menaposs Sheds Association provides safe spaces across the country for many, including socially isolated people, to meet, share good times, learn and refine DIY and other practical skills together. Charlie Bethel, chief officer at the UK Menaposs Sheds Association, said: It has long been recognised that DIY can be good for your well-being. Our sheds are inclusive, welcoming spaces where anyone can get involved in practicing their skills and our movement continues to make a huge dference to the lives of our members and the communities that they support.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA school in England has social distancing measures in place as it prepares to welcome pupils back on June . Kempsey Primary School in Worecstershire has been looking after  or so children of key workers during the lockdown. Some of the steps pupils are taking for their safety is a apostraffic lightapos system, which sees the children stand on spots while waiting to wash their hands. Other measures the school have taken include directional arrows on the floor to create a one-way system. Children also sit in segregated sections at lunchtime, with hot meals also prepared carefully for the local community. The tables are marked to show where pupils can sit at lunchtime and during classes. Bryony Barnes, head teacher, said the school is taking all precautionary measures to keep its pupils and staff safe when it reopens.She told Worcester News : Obviously this all depends on the governmentaposs five tests being met, but we are looking at what we can do to make sure the school is as safe as possible. It is a tricky one, but we are doing what we can to make it as safe as possible while also making the children and staff comfortable. We want them to be at ease as the school will obviously look and feel dferent when theyso we need to look at what we can do to reassure them and their parents and make them feel comfortable.Letters are being sent out to the parents, which will allow them to make their own decision about sending their children back to school. Staff are being trained on how to deal with pupils moving around the school while maintaining social distancing. Schools across England are preparing to open on June , despite concerns from parents and staff. But councils like Liverpool, Hartlepool and Bury have stated schools there will not reopen. Teaching unions warned the government’s evidence that reopening schools was safe from June  was “flimsy at best”. Gateshead Council leader Martin Gannon said: The national advice telling us the lockdown is over is frankly madness. Opening schools was meant to happen as part of the second phase of easing the lockdown, at the same pace across the UK.  But Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland have all broken ranks and refused to reopen schools as soon as June . Meanwhile, the government has shown signs that dferent regions of England could end up taking dferent approaches. The plan is for primary schools to start reopening in a phased way as early as June . They would begin with years R,  and  ing in the first week of June, followed by years , ,  and  before the beginning of July.  Schools are being told to halve class sizes to , prevent those mini-classes mixing with any other classes, and implement one-way corridors, staggered break and start times and extra cleaning. Secondary schools are largely not expected back before the summer break. The exception is Years  and , who would get some face-to-face time to help transition to the next year. Exams are cancelled. Ministers have said there are no plans to keep schools open during the summer holidays.Yesterday top Tory Michael Gove claimed he could guarantee teachers will be safe - but then immediately admitted they might catch coronavirus.Askedhe could guarantee teachers will be safe when classrooms reopen, Mr Gove told the BBCaposs Andrew Marr Show: Yes. I talked to the chief scientic advisor yesterday for the government, Patrick Vallance, and running through the figures - the R number, the rate of infection in the community overall - we’re confident that children and teachers will be safe.” Yet grilled over his claim, Mr Gove then admitted he could not guarantee all teachers would be safe. He said you can never eliminate risk and added: There is always, always, always, in any loosening of these restrictions, a risk of people catching the coronavirus.

The residents are all so lonely because they canapost have visitors and they miss their families, so itaposs nice to be the one bit of joy in their day. A lot are pining for company but you have to keep your distance so you canapost give them a pat on the shoulder or a hug. Ministers have told schools to get ready for reception, year one and six toon June  - but only when all the tests are met as it will be safe to do so. Officials have issued advice to headteachers on ensuring classrooms and playgrounds are as safe as possible with class sizes capped at  pupils and desks kept two metres apart. However teaching unions and the government have locked horns over whether itaposs safe for kids to go back to school on June . Furious union bosses have ordered their members to refuse to engage with the government and have a string of conditions that must be met before theyaposllto their classrooms. Liverpool, Bury, Hartlepool and Gateshead councils have all said they will not be reopening schools on June . Downing Street suggested that a final approval could come as early as this week. A spokesman didnapost challenge claims that the final decision could come this week as next week is half-term He said: You can see from the discussions that have taken place ... that we are working to seek to resolve this as soon as we can. Officials are adamant that nothing will happen before June  while the Government will publish its scientic advice and SAGE minutes on safety in schools as soon as possible.  Union leader Geoff Barton claimed today that the government will make the final decision next Thursday which coincides with the next three-week review into the lockdown. He said: It is also important to understand that the government will only make the final decision on whether to press ahead with the reopening of schools when it reviews the latest science on May , and thatthe evidence does not support this decision at that time, it will be delayed.Yesterday Cabinet Office minister Michael Gove said the government was aposconfident children and teachers will be safeapos when schools reopen.Speaking on the BBCaposs Andrew Marr show, he said: “The clear scientic and clinical advice is that it is safe to have schools reopen, accompanied with social distancing.  The Governmentaposs roadmap gives no specic date on when a decision will be made on any changed but they will be announced at least  hours in advance.The five tests set out by Boris Johnson must be met before any relaxing of the rules.The Prime Minister said at the weekend that three of those five have now been met with work being done on the other two. Parents have been promised they will not be punishedthey decide not to send their children to school.  Liverpool city council became the first local authority to announced it would not be reopening its schools on June . It said the earliest date for lessons to resume in the classroom will be June  and only year six, the oldest children, would be allowed back. Until then it will continue to allow only the children of key workers and vulnerable pupils to attend school. Hartlepool council and Gateshead council have announced they also plan to delay the reopening of their schools.  Last night policing minister Kit Malthouse hinted that some schools in some areas may reopen depending on their infection rates. He was asked on Radio aposs Westminster Hour last nightthat could lead to dferentrates for schools in dferent parts of the country, is that something that could happen  To which he replied: In theory it could. It’s certainly the reason for us setting up this new bio security centre, as I think was outlined when it was announced, so we can monitor the progress of the virus across the country. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThe UK will be treated to a Spring sizzler this week in what is expected to be the hottest day of the year.It comes after the whole country shivered through unseasonable cold weather last week, with the mercury rarely drting above the low-teens centigrade.As of today such stling chills can be consigned to mere memory as May gets back on track. Come Monday afternoon temperatures will be around the C mark in the south east, the high teens in the south west and the east, and around C in Wales and the north east. As those living there know to expect, Scotland and Northern Ireland will have the worst of it with temperatures between C and C. This will be caused by two weather fronts which may bring showers and dark clouds overhead. The high pressure in the east and south means the inclement weather will be kept at bay. Then things will really start to warm up on Tuesday. Large swathes of England will bask in hours of uninterrupted sunshine and thermometer readings in the low to mid s. The further north and west you are, the higher the likelihood clouds will gather overhead and take the edge off the heat. In Wales, the north west, Northern Ireland and Scotland temperatures will peak in the mid-teens at around pm.  Wednesday will be really warm. As with Monday and Tuesday, the south and east are expected to have the best of the weather. In Norfolk, Suffolk and Essex the mercury will sit in the mid twenties for most of the afternoon. In Wales and the south west, C or C can be expected, while Birmingham, Manchester and Liverpool are likely to see highs of C. Yorkshire and the north east, which are not always known for their balminess, may even hit the C mark. In Scotland the western coast will be slightly warmer than the east, where the pm sun may break through patchy clouds to take things to C or C. The hottest spot across the isles will be in London, where temperatures are creeping up into the high twenties.Bonnie Diamond, a Met Office forecaster, said: By Wednesday there will be low cloud to start the day, but this will lt quickly.It is expected to be the hottest day of the year so far with possibly C in London. The highest temps will be in eastern parts of England. York down to the east midlands could be C or higher.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA former cartel boss nicknamed ‘Big Nose’ has been arrested on suspicion of being involved in at least  murders including US Consulate workers and their families. Luis Gerardo, known by the aliases El Tioand El Narizon , was arrested on Saturday in the city of Cuernavaca, in the central Mexican state of Morelos with prosecutors linking him with over  murders. He is wanted in the United States on suspicion of being involved in the murder of US Consulate worker Leslie Ann Enriquez Catton, , and her husband, sherf Arthur Redelfs, , as well as the husband of another consulate employee Jorge Alberto Salcido Ceniceros, . Gerardo,  leader of the Los Aztecas armed wing of the Juarez Cartel, is believed to have masterminded the murders which Los Aztecas gang member Arturo Gallegos Castrellon, . Leslie Ann and her husband were killed when an armed gang fired shots at their car as they left a birthday party in March . The gang followed the car on Ciudad Juárez, Mexico, through the streets and riddle it with bullets, authorities said at the time. The couple died instantly, but their daughter was unhurt but left terried in her car seat in the back. Leslie Ann was four months pregnant at the time of the tragedy. They were innocent victims of the escalating violence in Juárez, Ruben Redelfs, Arthur Redelfsapos brother, said, according to the El Paso Times newspaper. Both my brother and his we had unblemished records where they worked and were not involved in anything wrong whatsoever, he said. They will be deeply missed. The other murdered consulate worker, Jorge Alberto Salcido Ceniceros, was killed when cartel members shot at his car at a separate location on the same day, also wounding his two young children.They had attended the same birthday party. The attackers had targeted consulate employees, but it was never clear why. The consulate killings were ordered by Jose Antonio Acosta Hernandez, who was in charge of the armed enforcement wing of the Juarez Drug Cartel. In total,  people were killed from that birthday party and a car bomb killed four others, including two Mexican police officers. Hernandez was sentenced to le in prison in  after authorities implicated him in more than , murders. He pleaded guilty to  counts that included murder, conspiracy to kill people in a foreign country and ious racketeering, money laundering and drug charges. Gerardo is believed to have been one of the leaders of Los Aztecas after they broke away from the Juarez Cartel and began working in trafficking drugs, including heroin, to the United States. He is also accused of ordering attacks on five rehabilitation centres in the city of Ciudad Juarez, in the state of Chihuahua, as well as the murder of women and children at the border between the United States and Mexico. The former gang leader allegedly masterminded the murder of at least  students aged between  and  in Ciudad Juarez in .

Her ex-boyfriend Tishko Ahmed Shabaz was arrested and has now been charged with her murder in a case that has shocked Sweden because it is deemed as one of the safest countries in the world, Expressen reports. Her head was found on November  bringing the missing person search to an end and the launch of a murder investigation. Prosecutors claim Wilma was subjected to aposrepeated violenceapos during her death. Wilmaaposs devastated mum Linda has issued an emotional appeal begging people to continue their search and help her to find the rest of her daughteraposs body.  She told Swedish media: We want to find our daughter and sister. It is completely inhumane that we go through so please do not stop looking for Wilma. I hope people are observantthey see something aberrant in water or terrain. That people have their eyes open. Relatives told police Wilma has visited Shabazaposs home to pick up her things after ending the relationship. Shabaz told Wilmaaposs parents that Wilma had left the flat alive but police say they found her coat and handbag still hanging in his wardrobe - his neighbours also said they heard screaming from his flat.

title: craig conway film jon daly dundee united scottish cup
story: Craig Conway has revealed he warmed up for Scottish Cup glory with Dundee United by watching “The Commitments” with Jon Daly.Conway’s two goals in the th and th minute, following David Goodwillie’s opener, secured the Cup for United in  and sealed the winger’s place in Tangerines folklore.Around , Terrors fans travelled through to Glasgow for the showpiece occasion, many wracked with nerves.But Conway was totally relaxed before producing his man-of-the-match performance.“The night before the Final I was sharing a room in the team hotel with big Jon Daly,” said the -year-old, currently with Salford City.“We just tried to have a quiet time and then watched the film The Commitments.“I didn’t really have trouble sleeping. To be fair, I am usually like that before a big game.“I had already gone through everything in my mind about what I wanted to do on the pitch and how to prepare.”Conway, who has also played for Cardf City and Blackburn Rovers, added: “There was little in the final itself as we went in at half-time with the scores level.“But I was always sure thatwe kept doing what we had been doing the first goal would come.“Thankfully it did and then I was able to get my two goals as well.“It is something you are always asked: ‘Is it the sort of thing you dream about when you are a kid,’ and genuinely it is.“When you are playing in the park with your mates, you hope that one day you can score in the Scottish Cup Final so to do it was one of the highlights of my career and one of the best feelings you can get.“Once the final whistle goes, it is all a bit of a blur but it was just great to see the sheer delight on everyone’s faces.“It is so hard to put into words exactly how you felt but there was a massive sense of achievement.”After the trophy was handed to United, the celebrations really took off on the way back to Dundee before the players partied the night away alongside ecstatic fans, with Conway heading for his favourite city night spot.“It was just carnage on the bus with all sorts of nonsense back to the club and then it was into the town to celebrate,” said the seven-times-capped ex-Scotland star.“I’d had a lot of nights out in Fatties but everyone was just having a great time and it was the best atmosphere ever there.“Everybody was absolutely buzzing and it was great to be able to celebrate with the fans.“Everyone was together like a big family.“After a couple of hours’ sleep, we then had the parade on the open-top bus.‘To be honest, a lot of us were still drunk! In fact the celebrations continued for most of that week.“We had expected the fans to turn out but we were absolutely stunned by the thousands in the city square and at Tannadice. It is something that will stay with me forever.“The  years have just flown by but there will always be a special bond with the lads.“It was one of the best days of my career and my medal still has pride of place in a room in my house.”For as little as £. a month you can access all of our content, including Premium articles.

title: dundee fc john nelms spfl
story: The result of Tuesday’s failed SPFL inquiry vote has vindicated Dundee managing director John Nelms, according to a Dark Blues fan chief.Following weeks of back-biting and sniping over the Dens Park supremo’s now infamous voting U-turn at the start of April, two thirds of league clubs voted against an independent inquiry.With nine out of  Championship clubs voting ‘no’, chairman of the Dundee Supporters# Association, Kenny Ross, believes a “clear statement” has been made in relation to Nelms# actions.And Ross also insists the response from Dundee fans at large has been one of acceptance.He told the Tele: “The club seem quite relaxed about what’s been going on the past couple of weeks, not saying anything.“John Nelms doesn’t say much at the best of times but I think that relaxed attitude is echoed by the fans.“With nine out of  Championship clubs voting no, there is also a clear statement there and I think it vindicates John Nelms.“Personally, I would have liked an inquiry because there are questions that need answered but it was pretty overwhelming from Dundee’s fellow Championship clubs and % of all the clubs that it wasn’t wanted.“It’s clear from that there isn’t really a problem from most clubs on the U-turn – the majority wanted it with over % voting that way and the Deloitte inquiry said there was no wrongdoing.“With reconstruction talks ending, fans do wonder what John Nelms achieved through the U-turn but I think we are all past it now. I’ve not had anyone on to me about it all, there’s very little online about this week’s vote – I don’t think anyone really cares now.”Rangers vehemently led the call for a vote on an independent inquiry into the SPFL’s conduct during the coronavirus shutdown, as well as Dundee’s actions in changing their vote.That led to Gers fans bombarding online posts from the club and DSA social media, but Ross believes the reaction from fellow Dundee supporters is telling.He added: “Anytime the DSA are posting stuff on social media, we have to go through and delete loads of stuff.“It’s almost amusing now – Dundee fans responding generally laugh at them. title: dundee organisations team up to support students during ramadan
story: A Dundee University society has teamed up with a local charity to deliver meals to anyone across the city who needs help breaking their fast during Ramadan.Dundee University Islamic Society is working in collaboration with Changemakers Yusuf Youth Initiative to help deliver meals to anyone in the community that might need help.Due to the coronavirus outbreak, Ramadan has been challenging for many as it has meant people cannot visit their local mosque or be with friends and family.Every year the Dundee Central Mosque offers free dinners for students and the local community to break their fasts, also known as Iftars.The partnership#s aim now is to deliver free -day Iftar packs with the makings of a home cooked meal as well as hot food.The project hopes to help build a community for students that aren’t local to Dundee and help get them through Ramadan.Shabana Stanikzai, president of Dundee University Islamic Society, said: “The blessed month of Ramadan is normally is a time of large gatherings in the mosques and community meals.“However, this year Ramadan is completely dferent as mosques are closed and social distancing measure are in place. Despite the unique circumstances this Ramadan, we are trying to stay positive.“Working with Changemakers and Dundee Central Mosque has been a great way to network students together so they aren#t alone this month and provide them with free food parcels throughout the month of Ramadan.”Lamia Farha, a student from Bangladesh currently being supported by the Iftar delivery service, said: “My experience of Ramadan has been challenging this year as I’ve missed the company of my friends and family.“Having the support with my Iftar meals has helped me stay strong both mentally and physically.“When my friend told me about the support being offered I knew it was something that I would really benefit from and I am very grateful for it.”Halima Kolo, project manager at Changemakers Yusuf Youth Initiative, said: “Fasting during Ramadan on a normal basis was always something the community looked forward to.“This is because, without fail, most people will host Iftar parties, some men and women will break their fast in the mosque and you’ll always be around people throughout the day.“However, this year, with the mosques being closed and everyone being at home we’re having to meet our friends virtually. Some people do weekly Ramadan reflections at the mosque, however this year the atmosphere is dferent.“The first day or two a lot of people really missed being at the mosque, bumping into the community elders who always shared word of wisdom with the youths, embracing each other at the mosques.”During the month of Ramadan, Muslims won#t eat or drink between dawn and sunset.To receive support during Ramadan or to find out how you can help please get in contact with the Dundee University Islamic Society.For as little as £. a month you can access all of our content, including Premium articles.
