title: let-borders-garden-centres-open-soon-says-msp
story: BORDERS residents should be allowed to visit garden centres soon, according to a politician.Christine Grahame MSP has asked the Scottish Government to consider re-opening such businesses with safety measures in place.Ms Grahame, of the SNP, highlighted the "physical and mental wellbeing benefits" of gardening.The member for Midlothian South, Tweeddale and Lauderdale addressed Holyroods rural economy and connectivity committee this morning.She said: ldquoAny re-opening of businesses of course needs to be done in a safe manner, giving proper consideration to the safety of both staff and the public."Irsquom optimistic that this may be possible with garden centres soon, given the physical and mental wellbeing benefits gardening can offer for us all in lockdown.ldquoIf yoursquore fortunate enough to have access to a garden it can make a real dference and being able to buy some supplies for it could be a real boost to many. Indeed even a window box can make a dference. While you can currently buy online, it is not as satisfactory.ldquoOur horticultural sector has been hit hard by lockdown, with many businesses losing out on what would be one of their busiest periods of trade in spring and early summer."This not only affects the big well known chains, but smaller local businesses and growers.ldquoI welcome news that this is being given serious consideration and I trust the Scottish Government will authorise re-opening soon."

title: john-lamont-cancels-summer-tour-first-time-14-years
story: A BORDERS politician has announced he is cancelling his summer surgery tour for the first time in more than a decade.John Lamont MP and Rachael Hamilton MSP, both Conservatives, had been due to visit  towns and villages over the summer.But with coronavirus restrictions in place, the pair are scrapping their plans.Mr Lamont, who formerly held Ms Hamiltons Holyrood seat, expressed sadness that he would be missing an annual "highlight" for himself.He said: "Irsquom really disappointed that for the first time in  years, it will not be happening this summer."The member for Berwickshire, Roxburgh and Selkirk ndash who won his first parliamentary election in  ndash said it is important to follow government advice aimed at limiting the spread of COVID-.He added that he continues to hold surgeries over the phone.Ms Hamilton, who represents Ettrick, Roxburgh and Berwickshire in the Scottish Parliament, said she is also "disappointed" about the tour cancellation.She added: "I am very much looking forward to meeting constituents again in hopefully the near future when the restrictions are safely lted."

title: borders-businessman-making-living-unwanted-trees
story: AN ENTREPRENEUR is enjoying success by helping to make houses, animal shavings and food pallets.Douglas Mathison, , of Peeblesshire, fells trees across the south of Scotland through his company Agrorest.ldquoEven with the poorest quality timber, you can still get a lot of use out of it, says Mr Mathison, explaining that unwanted woods on farms and estates have the potential to serve a iety of purposes.Once the timber has been taken to the sawmill, Mr Mathison says, the best of it gets transformed into timber-framed houses, while the scraps might ultimately line a rabbit hutch.When Agrorest was founded in , it served a role that was ldquounique in the south of Scotland, according to Mr Mathison.Established firms often shunned the type of tasks that Agrorest expressed an interest in, he says.ldquoWhen I first started, we were the only one in the south of Scotland that was doing this work on a very small basis, Mr Mathison says.ldquoWersquove been taking on an increasing workload, focusing on smaller jobs that other companies are not interested in working on.Although there are now three or four other firms carrying out a similar role in the region, according to Mr Mathison, Agrorest continues to field enquiries from Kilmarnock to West Linton and beyond.Explaining the typical process, Mr Mathison says an initial phone call will often lead to a site visit, which in turn results in Mr Mathison estimating the potential financialthat could be made on a patch of woodlandfelled.If the farmer wishes to press ahead and Mr Mathison secures a licence from Scottish Forestry, Agrorest will send in the machinery, remove the trees and take the timber to sawmills.The farmer can be paid within a few weeks, according to Mr Mathison, who shares a portion of the money he receives from the mills.Aside from felling, Agrorest carries out replanting and also manages a number of estates.Mr Mathison says his success has overcome a historical perception among certain landowners that woodland is ldquonot worth bothering about.In his experience, he says, an undermanaged patch of trees will be worthy of attention ldquonine times out of .Mr Mathison is a former Peebles High School pupil who went on to study rural business management in Edinburgh.He launched Agrorest after a stint working for a large timber harvesting company.

title: 22m-coronavirus-support-approved-borders-businesses
story: MORE than pound million in coronavirus support has been approved for Borders businesses.Scottish Borders Councilhas been managing a portion of the Scottish Governmentrsquos Business Support Fund.More than , payments have now been processed, according to the local authority, amounting to a total of pound. million.Two forms of one-off help are available ndash a pound, grant and a pound, grant, with dfering eligibility criteria.Application forms can be accessed here.

title: 2-000-payments-approved-self-employed-people-borders
story: SELF-EMPLOYED people in the Borders have started receiving money from the council in the form of coronavirus support.The Newly Self-Employed Hardship Fund was launched on May .Since then,  people have been approved for a one-off payment of pound,, according to Scottish Borders Council.The money has been made available by the Scottish Government, with people eligible to applythey set up in business on or after April , .

title: golfers-raise-10-000-peebles-golf-club
story: GOLFERS have donated more than pound, to help Peebles Golf Club while the course is closed.The clubs fundraising drive, launched after the coronavirus lockdown, collected more than pound, last month.Les Biscomb, of the clubs sponsorship sub-committee, hailed the generosity of donors.Reflecting on the campaign so far, he said: ldquoItrsquos been a tremendous success."Unlike golf clubs south of the border, Scottish courses remain closed ndash meaning clubhouse coffers continue to struggle.But the idea of setting up a fundraiser in Peebles has already been vindicated, according to Mr Biscomb.He said: "As a team, we came up with the idea of, while wersquore in lockdown, our members might have vastly reduced income ndash theyrsquore being paid to work at home or are pensioners ndash but therersquos nowhere to spend your money at the moment."You canrsquot go to golf, you canrsquot go down the pub, you canrsquot go to restaurants, many people arenrsquot driving anywhere, so we thought, while wersquore in lockdown, why donrsquot we ask the members in Peebles, who are kindhearted and generous, to put something each month towards a crowdfunder.Comments by donors on the website include, Have my coffee money for the coming month otherwise Irsquoll probably fritter it away and Glad to donate again to ensure our club survives.The sub-committee originally set a target of pound, each month, but received more than pound, in April.Mr Biscomb said: ldquoWe would have been delightedwersquod raised the pound, but in the very first month alone we got to pound,."Some of those were one-offs, so people just wanted to join in with the giving and the spirit of helping the club but even so,you look at May, wersquore already at pound,.ldquoWe were hoping for this to continue for two or three months, pound, a month, just to add in the coffers."This isnrsquot funding thatrsquos needed immediately ndash from a cash perspective, Peebles is doing well."This is really for the quiet periods. Once we turn the corner into next year, thatrsquos really when we might need this money, in the quieter days.ldquoBut who knows whatrsquos going to happen with lockdown, and when wersquore going to get cash back through other means, like the bar and catering, and visitors.Currently, all club staff are on furlough, with the exception of head greenkeeper Steve Borthwick.ldquoSteversquos going a fantastic job, said Mr Biscomb. "The course is in magnicent condition ndash it is very tempting to get out there.Meanwhile, British Prime Minister Boris Johnson has announced that golf clubs in England can re-open, as long as social distancing guidelines are followed.Mr Biscomb conceded he is "quite jealous", but indicated he is satisfied with the Scottish rules.He said: ldquoIrsquod love to get out on the golf course. But equally, we understand that the Scottish Government is not ready because the stats are not there."Theyrsquore not comfortable with opening golf clubs and we have to respect that."Hopefully, in a few weeksrsquo time,the number [of virus cases] comes down, we can start to get out in ones and twos."For now, we have to live with it and be sensible."Wersquore in the eighth week already ndash another couple of weeks wonrsquot do any harm."Itrsquos achievable to be sensible for another few weeks.Donations to Peebles Golf Club can be made via: www.justgiving crowdfunding pgcmembersappealfund

title: mountain-bikers-told-ride-within-limits-lockdown
story: MOUNTAIN bikers have been issued with guidance during lockdown.Scottish Cyclinghas outlined a series of dos and donts following the Scottish Governments go-ahead for people to exercise more than once a day.There are four rules cyclists and mountain bikers must adhere to under the new SC guidelines:Only ride from your home ndash it is not essential travel to go mountain biking or cycling and you may face enquiries from the policeyou are stopped en route or ing from a ride. All Forestry and Land Scotland car parks and trails, including the stanes sites, remain closedDo not go far ndash whilst you can go exercise for longer, we recommend riding close to where you live and not into remote areas ndash think more smaller loops rather than one longer remote rideRide well within your limits ndash only ride on trails that are that you are very confident you will be able to ride safely and within your competency. It is highly unlikely that mountain rescue are back to full operations ndash consider the fact that a full rescue may not be possible and may take longer to get to youOnly cycle with members of your own household - keep a safe distance when passing other cyclists or pedestrians.Mountain biking trails such as the stanes at Glentress, Peebles, and Innerleithen are closed until further notice to restrict travel to the trails and for safety as they are not being maintained as they were before lockdown.However, walking trails owned by Forestry and Land Scotland are open to members of the public who can access them without using transport.

title: subway-store-galashiels-busy-since-re-opening
story: SUBWAY in Galashiels has re-opened for takeaway and delivery.The sandwich store, which had closed due to coronavirus restrictions, welcomed customers back this week.The Channel Street premises opened its doors again on Monday , applying social distancing guidance and using protective gear.Store supervisor Imran Han said the shop has been "busy".

title: borders-lib-dems-select-ettrick-roxburgh-berwickshire-candidate
story: THE Liberal Democrats have selected a candidate for next years Holyrood election.Jenny Marr will stand for the Ettrick, Roxburgh and Berwickshire constituency ndash currently held by Conservative Rachael Hamilton.The former Selkirk High pupil said: "Irsquom thrilled to have been chosen to represent Ettrick, Roxburgh and Berwickshire for the Scottish Liberal Democrats."We are living in extraordinary times and I have been blown away by how communities across the Borders have rallied to support each other."The most important thing we can do as politicians and political parties is to provide assistance to anyone that needs it, learn from our experiences and work to address inequalities which have manest."The vote is set to take place on Thursday, May  of next year.

title: borders-based-msp-introduces-online-advice-surgeries
story: A BORDERS-BASED MSP is introducing video surgeries for his constituents.Paul Wheelhouse, who represents the South of Scotland, has had to temporarily close his Hawick office due to the coronavirus outbreak.But from next Friday, Borderers will be able to have a face-to-face meeting ndash without leaving their homes.Mr Wheelhouse said: "Video advice surgeries will be secure and confidential. Constituents will be able to talk to me as though we were sitting down together in person."I fully appreciate that many people do not have video-conferencing technology, or do not even have the internet in their home. For those people, my office is still contactable by telephone at this time."The online advice surgeries are to complement, not replace, other forms of communication. I would strongly encourage anyone who needs my support to get in touch, either by email or phone, and myself and my team will assist in any way we can."Mr Wheelhousersquos first online surgery will take place from pm on Friday, May .To make an appointment, email: paul.wheelhouse.msp@parliament.scot

title: 75-students-without-laptop-get-device-borders-college
story: BORDERS College has loaned laptops to  students who did not have regular access to a suitable device at home.With face-to-face classes cancelled due to coronavirus restrictions, learning has been taking place remotely.Student who did not have adequate laptops of their own have been allowed to borrow from the Galashiels campus.Sport and exercise student Harrison Dixon, from Earlston, said he was "delighted" with the scheme.He said: ldquoMy personal computer is old and struggling to work with some of the new applications and online resources that we are now using, so I spoke with my course tutor who made me aware of the loan scheme, and I was delighted when it was delivered last week."Having the laptop will allow me to continue with my studies remotely.The college says it has loaned a total of  laptops, including those allocated through its bursary programme.Head of IT Scott Moncrieff said: ldquoBefore the college closed, we were able to prepare and distribute  laptops to students for use."Since lockdown, we have had an additional  requests, which we have been able to fulfil.ldquoAny students who find themselves in the situation that continuing their education is not possible, because they donrsquot have an appropriate device, should contact their course tutor or achievement coach, and they will make the appropriate arrangements.

title: historic-borders-houses-feature-visitscotland-campaign
story: HISTORIC homes in the Borders are featuring in a social media campaign by VisitScotland.The tourist organisation has launched #AWindowOnScotland, which asks people to take a photo from their window.Traquair House, Peeblesshire, is among the stately homes in the Borders taking part, with views from the th century Aikwood Tower, near Selkirk, also being shared across social media.Gillian Steele, chairwoman of Big Houses in the Scottish Borders, said: "I donrsquot think people will necessarily forget we are here, but with us all looking out of our windows dreaming of that day when we can travel again, and indulge our passion for Scottish heritage, this campaign strikes a chord."VisitScotlandrsquos #AWindowOnScotland campaign provides us with a great visual opportunity to continue to promote our Houses, their gardens and their wildle from the same perspective as everyone at home."Irsquom encouraging all the Big Houses to take part, and I hope between the eleven of us we will give visitors a reminder of how beautul our Houses and gardens look this month."The campaigns hashtag has been used , times, with towns and villages across the Borders taking part.Historic buildings participating include Thirlestane Castle, near Lauder, and Mellerstain House, near Kelso.VisitScotlands regional leadership director Paula Ward said: ldquoWersquore thrilled at the reaction to #AWindowOnScotland from residents across the Scottish Borders and heartened that businesses are engaging with the campaign and using the opportunity to share their windows on Scotland with the world during this challenging time.ldquoThe staycation market will be a key driver in the countryrsquos economic recovery and the many wonderful views people have been sharing while they stay at home will surely be an incentive for many to travel when the time comes.ldquoThe campaign is far from over and wersquod encourage residents and businesses to continue posting their views, however they may look, as it is all Scotland, to help lt the spirits of those at home and abroad.To join the campaign, take a photo of a view from your window and share it online using #AWindowOnScotland, then tag your location.

title: national-express-plans-resume-coach-services-july-1
story: National Express has started selling UK coach tickets as it plans to restart services on July .The tickets will be available for a "core coach network" andwill focus on large and medium-sized towns and cities.Revenue dropped about  per cent in April compared withthe same month last year, National Express revealed, as the Government advised Britons to keep away from public transport.Nevertheless, Ebitdawas positive and slightly ahead of expectations as National Express slashed costs by about pound million.What hasNational Express said In a statement to customers, National Express said: "We have extended the temporary suspension of our coach services."A restricted timetable is currently scheduled to resume from Wednesday, July , ."Please note, however, all services are subject to change depending on Government advice."For thosethat have an upcoming journey booked with us on or before June ,  and would like to amend your booking, you can do so for free, for travel any time in the next  months."There is no need to contact us straight away, just completeour ticket amendment formbefore your original outward journey and get back in touch with us when yoursquore ready to travel again."If you do not wish to amend your ticket to another date, we will provide a full refund. If you havenrsquot already done so, please completeour refund formand we will process your refund within  days."Please stay safe and well and, when the time is right, we look forward to welcoming you back on board."Where does National Express travel to The company runs coach services across the UK, including Manchester to Coventry, London to Worthing, Newcastle via Darlington to London, Liverpool to Leeds, Edinburgh and Glasgow to London, plus Bradford to London.

title: graphic-designer-reveals-inspired-borders-kids
story: A GRAPHIC designer is helping to keep families entertained during lockdown after creating free colouring packs.Kate Pearson, , who owns K Graphic Design, has created six art packs to help ease the boredom of being stuck indoors.Kate, of Peebles, said: "I absolutely love my job because I get to be creative every day."Each pack features dferent activities for children ndash and adults ndash including colouring, design, and games like word searches.Kate said: "Just before lockdown, I spoke to the pupils at my old primary school, Priorsford Primary School, about my career."I left feeling inspired by their enthusiasm and the idea of activity packs was born."She had planned to print the packs but wanted them to be accessible so made them digital ndash a decision which has paid off.The downloads page on her website has been visited more than , times in the last two months, she said.Kate ensured that each pack had something for everyone, with themes including rainbows and dinosaurs."They were designed with young people in mind, but have proved to be just as popular with adults ndash especially the dinosaur one," said Kate.Kate also owns Glass Bulldog Wedding Stationary, and with wedding fairs for  cancelled or postponed, both sides of her business have taken a knock."Ninety per cent of my bookings have been cancelled or postponed until next year ndash many of my suppliers are affected too," said Kate."I really feel for all businesses facing closure and couples postponing their weddings."Like everyone, the biggest challenge of COVID- is not seeing friends and family, but staying at home is such a small price to pay to stay safe ndash especially now lsquoNeighboursrsquo is back on five days a week!"Kate ed to Peebles only a few years ago, after enjoying multiple career roles including as a wedding planner and working for a London-based design agency.Looking to the future, Kate already has three new packs in mind and hopes to eventually print the activity books.She also hopes that once the Borders s to normal, many of her usual services will be back up and running, especially those catered for weddings and events."My clients range from small local start-ups to The Botanic Gardens and Amazon ndash no two days are the same," she said."Going freelance also means I can take my dog, Dr Frankenstein, to work. What more could you ask for "

title: tesco-clubcard-vouchers-set-expire-extended-november-2020
story: A BATCH of Tesco Clubcard vouchershave been extended by the supermarket.The extension comes as Tesco says customers across the UK have not been shopping as frequently as before the lockdown period began in March.Herersquos everything you need to know.Changing shopping habitsWith some customers unable to visit stores at all during lockdown, and others visiting less frequently, shopping habits have changed over the past few months.Tesco has reported that visits to the supermarket have halved since lockdown, but basket sizes have doubled.Clubcard vouchers extendedHowever, those with Clubcard vouchers could now be struggling to spend them before they expire,they cannot get to a store or book a delivery slot.Tesco has therefore issued a statement to shoppers stating that Clubcard points that were due to expire this month will now be extended, Manchester Evening News reports.Zoe Evans, of Tescos customer engagement centre, said:"We appreciate that, for many reasons, most of us arenrsquot shopping as often as we did before lockdown."As a little help from Clubcard, we want to give you more time to use your vouchers which were due to expire on May , ."Any vouchers issued in May  will now not expire until November , , giving you an extra six months to use them."Well update the expiry date on your digital vouchers, and well continue to accept paper vouchers in-store until the extended expiry date. We really hope it helps, and take care."

title: asda-employees-galashiels-start-using-electric-vehicles
story: STAFF at Asda in Galashiels have started using electric vehicles at work.The vehicles are being used to help with the click and collect service.Previously, delivery vans moved items from the store to the click and collect lockers across the car park.But now the task is performed by the electric vehicles, freeing up the vans to carry out more home deliveries.Asda director Emma Ford said: ldquoWe are always looking for ways to innovate in areas where customers care, while still providing an excellent customer experience.ldquoThese vehicles allow us to do this by increasing capacity for click and collect customers and enabling us to understand how we can better utilise electric vehicles across our fleet.The fully road-legal electric vans will allow all UK stores with a click and collect service to increase their slot availability from , to , per week, according to Asda.

title: borders-golfers-allowed-play-says-msp
story: BORDERS golfers and anglers should be allowed toto action, according to Rachael Hamilton.The Conservative MSP says she has written to the Scottish Government in a bid to get restrictions lted on outdoor activities.Mrs Hamilton said shooting and angling are among the activities which make an "immense contribution" to the rural economy.She said: "Outdoor sports, such as golfing, hiking and fishing, could take place with the necessary social distancing measures and it would not jeopardise the governmentrsquos efforts in tackling this pandemic."Prime Minister Boris Johnson announced last week that residents in England canto certain outdoor pursuits, including tennis and golf.But the Scottish Government has decided to retain the stay at home message, while now allowing people to exercise more than once a day.Mrs Hamilton, who represents Ettrick, Roxburgh and Berwickshire, says she has written to the Scottish cabinet secretary for rural economy and tourism, Fergus EwingMrs Hamilton, the shadow secretary, said: "We currently have an extraordinary situation in my constituency, around Coldstream, where people can happily fish in the English half of the River Tweed, whilst anglers in Scotland can only watch on from the Scottish side, where fishing is still not permitted at this time."By their nature, outdoor-based sports see participants spread out, whether over a hillside, across an open space or along a river."In the Borders and across rural Scotland, the angling and shooting industry needs to have clarity so it can plan for the new season."I urge the Scottish Government to rethink its restrictions, given the nature of these sports, and the immense contribution they make to our rural economy."

title: international-space-station-see-uk-live
story: DETAILS of how and when to spot the International Space Station above the UK at night have been revealed.The stationflies above our heads constantly, and orbits the planet every  minutes at a height of over  miles.Of course, its impossible to see during the day, but at night - and with the space stations orbit passing over Britain just so - it takes on the appearance of a bright star moving across the sky.It can actually be startling when you first spot it - a glowing orb without the telltale flashes of an aircrafts wing drting silently through the dark - but the station passes overhead fairly frequently.It goes through periods when we wont be able to see it for months, as its diagonal orbit crosses other parts of the planet, but every now and then, there comes a space of a few weeks when it flies overhead - and at night.Times y ever so slightly depending on your location, but weve used those given by NASAs Spot the Station website for Lancaster - the closest point we could find to the geographical centre of the UK - to try to give a good average.Here are the dates and times of when the station will become visible, with details ofhow long it will be in the sky in brackets. Heres when to see it:May  - .am May  - :am May  - :am May  - :pm May  - :pm May  - :am May  - :am May  - :pm May  - :am May  - :am May  - :am May  - :pm May  - :pm May  - :am May  - :am May  - :pm May  - :am May  - :am May  - :pm May  - :pm May  - :am May  - :pm May  - :am May  - :pm May  - :pm May  - :am May  - :pm May  - :am May  - :pm May  - :pm May  - :pm May  - :am May  - :pm May  - :pm May  - :pm For more information, and for timings more specic to where you live, visit NASAs Spot the Station website- spotthestation.nasa.gov.How do I see it You should have no trouble spotting the International Space Station as it drts overhead - we say drt, but its actually travelling at more than , mph.The station takes on the appearance of a bright star, and is usually much brighter than anything  in the sky.Sometimes the station will rise over the horizon other times it might fade into view in the middle of the night sky as it enters into the suns light.It will always appear in the west, and will travel eastwards.,params: .pushAnd just as it appears, it may disappear in the same way, growing fainter and fainter until its completely enshrouded by the Earths shadow.Youll easily be able to spot it with the naked eye , though even modestly priced binoculars may be able to pick out some of the stations details, like its large solar .So take a look up, theres a good chance youll spot the International Space Station, and it can be amazing to think there are actually people living up there and conducting experiments within the space environment.The experiments that they carry out would be almost impossible to replicate on earth.

title: colouring-packs-given-borders-sheltered-housing-residents
story: STAFF at sheltered housing in Innerleithen have gted activity packs to residents.Tenants of Mercer Court, in the townrsquos Angle Park, have been relieved of lockdown boredom after the generosity of Hanover Scotland employees.Items given to residents include word searches, crosswords, colouring-in packs, pens and pencils.Mercer Court development manager Kathleen Ewart said the response has been "grand", adding: "On the whole, itrsquos gone down well.Some of the kit was bought by staff, while other pieces were donated by the owner of the Treasure Island gt shop, Martha Gibson.Ms Ewart said: ldquoThe residents were getting a bit fed up, the longer lockdown was going on, so I thought it was time to find something to help pass the time.ldquoSome of our tenants have been able to get out for walks but some are shielding, some have health issues that mean it wouldnrsquot be appropriate for them to go out, some of them are of an age where they want to stay in even though theyrsquore mobile ndash theyrsquore a bit scared to go out.ldquoI knew that some of them liked doing things like crosswords and word searches, some people like colouring in, so we put things like that in the pack.ldquoI bought the activities but didnrsquot have enough colouring pens, so contacted Martha at Treasure Island to seeshe had any in her shop and she gave us a lot for free.Ms Ewart added: ldquoThe colouring in has gone down really well, and some of them have coloured the pictures in and given them back, so Irsquove laminated them and put them up."

title: nicola-sturgeon-lockdown-restrictions-eased-may-28---know
story: DETAILS of how Scotland will ease lockdown restrictions will be published laterthis week.The First Minister today revealed that the Scottish Government will publish a route map for the paths out of lockdown.She said thatprogress is being made in reducing the spread of the virus, changes could be made after the next review date of May .This would come after taking into account the reproduction rateof the virus, alongside the findings of the weekly National Records of Scotlandreport.Ms Sturgeon said changes could include some sporting events being allowed, including golf and fishing, as well as the opening of garden centres.Other potential easings includeletting people meet those from other households, provided social distancing is followed.The First Minister also said that more will be said about when schools might reopen.The First Minister said at the briefing: ldquoWithin two weeks, my hope is that we will be taking some concrete steps on the journey back to normality.ldquoAs Irsquove said before, it wonrsquot be normality as we knew it because the virus will not have gone away, but it will be a journey to a better balance ndash I hope ndash than the one we have today.ldquoAs we take each step, we must make sure that the ground beneath us is as solid as possible.ldquoThatrsquos why sticking with the lockdown restrictions a bit longer to suppress the virus more is so important, because that will mean we can start to take these steps with the confidence that we have alternative means of effectively keeping it under control.The First Minister said for the moment there is no change to the lockdown advice currently being circulated by the Scottish Government.

title: coronavirus-scotland-many-cases-live
story: The latest coronavirus figures for Scotland have been released.Earlier, speaking at the latest Scottish Government coronavirus briefing in Edinburgh, the First Ministerrevealed patients have died in Scotland after testing positive for coronavirus, up two from  on Sunday.She issued a note of caution over the death figures, saying although these can be registered at the weekend, registrations tend to be lower.Nicola Sturgeonsaid there are  patients in hospital with confirmed or suspected Covid-, up  from  on Sunday.Of these,  are in intensive care, a rise of four.Now, a breakdown of the figures hasbeen released for each health board.Greater Glasgow and Clyde remains the health board in Scotland with the most cases.There,  people are confirmed to have had the virus to date - with  confirmedcases in hospital and  in intensive care.In NHS Lothian, there are  cases.There,  people are in hospital with confirmed coronavirus, with half the number of Glasgows intensive care cases.On the westcoast, Ayrshire is nearing  confirmed cases, currently sitting at  - with  people in hospital and five in intensive care.And in the Borders,  people have had the virus to date.They have  people in hospital, with less than five people in intensive care.

title: borders-mp-reveals-rejected-bid-help-farmers
story: A BORDERS politician has defended himself after rejecting an opportunity to ban imports of low quality meat.John Lamont MP was among the Westminster parliamentarians who turned down an attempt to protect food standards last week.But Mr Lamont, of the Conservatives, says the UK Government will ensure British farmers are not hurt by future trade deals.He said: ldquoCritically, we will maintain our import standards, which include the ban on chlorine-washed chicken and hormone-injected beef.Some farming figures criticised politicians for failing to back Neil Parish MPrsquos amendment to the Agriculture Bill in the House of Commons on May .Mr Parish said the amendment aimed to make sure food imports are produced to the equivalent standards upheld in the UK.NFU Scotlandrsquos director of policy Jonnie Hall said it was ldquodeeply disappointing that the amendment lost by  votes.Mr Lamont told the Border he was ldquounable to support all of the amendments.The member for Berwickshire, Roxburgh and Selkirk added: ldquoThe government has made it clear that no UK import standards will be diminished as part of any free trade agreement.ldquoWe will also not undermine our high domestic environmental protection, animal welfare and food safety standards by ensuring in any agreement British farmers are always able to compete.ldquoI know that the UK Government is working very closely with industry figures to get the best trade deal that will allow Scottish farming to flourish.The Agriculture Bill passed its third reading in the House of Commons and will now be considered by the House of Lords.

title: happened-councils-first-virtual-meeting
story: TODAYsaw an unusual, yet historic, occasion for Scottish Borders Councilas it held its first virtual committee meeting since lockdown began.A total of nine councillors participated in the meeting of the planning and building standardscommittee, which gave approval for a houseto be built in Newstead.Chairman Tom Miers, a Conservative representative for Leaderdale and Melrose, said the meeting "went well given the circumstances".Journalists were allowed to view proceedings, conducted through Microsoft Teams, after the council made a U-turn on its original decision to ban the press.Mr Miers said: "Its not as good as meeting face to face. I would prefer to be able to have public input into the meetings, which is hard to do remotely."Also, it may be harder to have detailed technical discussion on matters of process in this medium at future meetings."Wersquoll see, and wersquoll adapt as necessary to make it as good as possible."We were able to conduct a full discussion of the issues and we heard a range of views from dferent councillors. So the PBS committee fulfilled its remit properly."Dreaded technical dficulties reared their head on several occasions, however ndash some councillors struggled with muting and un-muting their microphones.After they backed an application to build a house, Mr Miers reminded elected members that feedback was welcome on how the meeting went.As affairs drew to a close, conversation turned to facial hair grown since the last face-to-face meeting on March .One officer said his new beard "wont be lasting long".JS Crawford Farming Partnership has won permission to build a property on the corner of Main Street and Eddy Road.

title: everyone-aged-five-covid-19-symptoms-can-get-tested-hancock-says
story: Everyone aged five and over is now eligible to be tested for coronavirusthey are showing symptoms, which have been expanded to included a loss of taste or smell.Health Secretary Matt Hancock drastically increased the number of people who can get tested for Covid- across the UK on Monday, with the Government trying to track the spread of the disease in order to ease the lockdown.His announcement in the House of Commons came after the UKrsquos chief medical officers added the loss of, or noticeable change to, taste and smell to the NHSrsquos list of coronavirus symptoms, weeks after experts first raised concerns that cases were being missed.Anyone suffering the newly-added symptoms, or a continuous cough or high fever, should self-isolate for seven days to risk the spread of infection, and anyone they live with should stay home for  days.Previously only essential workers, the over-s and iniduals who live with them could apply for coronavirus testing on the NHS websitethey were showing symptoms.Mr Hancock said he was ldquoexpanding eligibility for testing further than ever before as ministers try to hit the new goal of having the ability to carry out , tests per day by the end of the month.ldquoI can announce to the House that everyone aged five and over with symptoms is now eligible for a test, he told MPs. ldquoThat applies right across the UK in all four nations from now.Mr Hancock also said that , contact tracers, including , health care professionals, had been recruited in England to help track people who have come into contact with infected iniduals.The tracers will advise them whether they need to enter self-isolation in an effort to drive down the spread of the virus.vw,vw,px, px"Along with the NHS app being ldquosuccessfully piloted, Mr Hancock said ministers now have the ldquoelements we need to roll out the test and trace programme.But he said the Government is ldquoperfectly prepared to hire more tracers after surpassing the target of employing ,.Downing Street said earlier that the app would be up and running in the coming weeks in England, even though Mr Hancock said last week it would be rolled out in mid May.Regarding symptoms, until now the NHS  coronavirus symptom checker has only listed high temperature and cough as the symptoms that require further action.Englandrsquos deputy chief medical officer, Professor Jonathan Van-Tam, told reporters adding loss of smell and taste to the list would mean % of cases where people have symptoms are now picked up, a rise from % previously.It comes after a study led by Professor Tim Spector at Kingrsquos College London found that % of Covid--positive patients reported loss of smell and taste, compared with only % of those who tested negative for the disease.vw,vw,px, px"Speaking about the findings on April , Prof Spector called for the rules to change, saying those with a loss of smell or taste needed to self-isolate.On Monday he heavily criticised the Governmentrsquos stance so far, saying infected people had been encouraged back to work due to a failure to track symptoms properly.He said between , and , cases had been missed.He blamed Public Health Englandand the wider strategy, saying an insistence that only fever and cough were the major symptoms had missed thousands of cases.He said: ldquoWe list about  symptoms which we Please contact graphics@pamediagroup.The World Health Organisationlisted loss of smell and taste as ldquoless common symptoms several weeks ago and other countries, including the US, added the symptom.Despite these warnings, Prof Van-Tam said on April  that the New and Emerging Respiratory Virus Threats Advisory Grouphad looked at the issue and concluded loss of smell or taste should not be added to the UKrsquos symptom list.But on Monday, that guidance was changed, with Prof Van-Tam saying advisers had needed to look at the issue in detail.He said scientists had had to ldquowork out very carefully how valid loss of taste or smell were in counting cases and where in the course of an illness the symptoms might occur.He said establishing how adding the symptom to the list could help pick up more cases had been ldquoquite a dficult piece of science.Prof Van-Tam told reporters at the daily Number  press briefing that just .% of  laboratory-confirmed coronavirus cases reported loss of smell on its own as a symptom.He also said that only once there was a vaccine that is ldquoreally capable of suppressing disease levelswill the country be ldquoout of this.He added: ldquoSo from that perspective we may have to live, and learn to live, with this virus in the long-term, certainly for many months to comenot several years.Prof Van-Tam also told the briefing the UK testing programme needed to be ldquobigger and faster.He added: ldquoWe are sending a clear message as scientists that it needs to be fast and we need to work as hard as we can to improve the timeliness of the testing system as we go along.Scottish First Minister Nicola Sturgeon welcomed the expansion of testing, adding: ldquoThis is vital in order to keep transmission in communities low..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagagaga, title: Everyone aged five and over with Covid- symptoms can get tested, Hancock says

title: former-pm-tony-blair-backs-government-bid-reopen-schools
story: Boris Johnsonrsquos administration is right to start reopening schools, former Labour prime minister Tony Blair has said.The Governmentrsquos plans to start sending children back to school next month has come under attack from teaching unions and some local authorities, with critics arguing it is too soon to lt the coronavirus-related lockdown restrictions.Prime Minister Mr Johnson, in his address to the nation on May , said Reception, Y and Y pupils would be the first to go back, starting on June  ldquoat the earliest.His ambition, Mr Johnson said, was that secondary pupils scheduled to take exams next year would ldquoget at least some time with their teachers before the holidays.Despite criticism of the proposals in some quarters, Mr Johnson has found an unlikely ally in three-time general election winner Mr Blair.In an interview with BBC Newsnight, due to be broadcast on Monday evening, the PM of  years said the Government was adhering to scientic advice by preparing schools to open their doors again.ldquoTheyrsquore right, I think, to be reopening the schools, said Mr Blair.ldquoI donrsquot think they would say that theyrsquore putting school opening above health risks. What theyrsquore doing is basing it on the evidence, actually.vw,vw,px, px"Prime Minister Boris Johnson has signalled some children couldfull-time to class as soon as June  ldquoThere are countries that have reopened parts, at least, of their school system.Health Secretary Matt Hancock looked to reassure the House of Commons on Monday, telling MPs only a ldquovery small number of children were ldquobadly affected by Covid-.Mr Blair backed up the comments, telling the BBC his own institute ndash the Tony Blair Institute for Global Change ndash had gathered data to show that ldquoespecially for younger children, the risks of transmission are actually quite low.The former Downing Street incumbent argued that private schools had been continuing to educate their pupils, while youngsters in the state system had been given ldquono education at all since schools were told to shut their gates on March  as the coronavirus outbreak took hold.ldquoLetrsquos be clear, the private schools will have been educating their children throughout this, added Mr Blair, a father of four.ldquoParts of the state system will have been. But then there are some children who will have been having no education at all. Yoursquove got to get the schools back.vw,vw,px, px"Social-distancing measures as a child studies on a marked table at Kempsey Primary School in Worcester. Nursery and primary pupils couldto classes from June  following the announcement of plans for a phased reopening of schools Union leaders remain unconvinced with the argument put forward by ministers and Mr Blair, however.Paul Whiteman, general secretary of school leadersrsquo union NAHT, told BBC Radio rsquos Today programme that teachers ldquohavenrsquot yet seen the scientic underpin to back up the assertion that the transmission risk among pupils is low.He has called on ministers to write to unions explaining the Governmentrsquos assessment.Bury Council, following in the footsteps of a number of other local authorities, told its schools this week that they would not reopen ldquowhile high levels of Covid- remain.Following growing opposition to the plan to reopen primaries to certain year groups from June , Bury council says that while high levels of the infection remain in the north west, ldquothe borough will not be re-opening schools on June .During the same interview, Mr Blair also gave his approval to the way Sir Keir Starmer has been leading Labour during the pandemic since his election as leader in April.ldquoItrsquos changed for the better, for sure, in my view, Mr Blair said of the current state of the party.ldquoBecause itrsquos got a serious leadership thatrsquos already making an impact because theyrsquore showing competence, forensic skill, in dissecting the Government.ldquoI think hersquos done a very good job so far and I wish him every success..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagagaga, title: Former PM Tony Blair backs Government bid to reopen schools

title: singer-proves-internet-sensation-showing-support
story: Among vocalist Lorraine McBreartyrsquos repertoire is a performance of lsquoYoursquoll Never Walk Alonersquo ndash the UKrsquos current number one single featuring Captain Tom Moore, Michael Ball and the NHS Voices Of Care Choir, which is raising funds for the NHS.Armed with a portable PA system, Lorraine, who is also a family worker at Northesk Church, sings outside her flat on Bridge Street after lsquoClap for Carersrsquo at pm, in a bid to cheer up local residents during the lockdown.ldquoIrsquoll keep popping out and doing one while we are in this situation or until folk get fed up, said Lorraine, who works as a dentist.She added that people around the world have watched the Facebook Live videos recorded by her teenage son, Adam Fotheringhame.She explained: ldquoI decided to do it as I sing in the band Back lsquonrsquo Blue at the weekend and miss singing.ldquoAlso, itrsquos all I can do to help cheer people up and feel part of a community.ldquoAs a dentist Irsquom limited at the moment, and my job as a church worker is all online. It is just outside my flat as I havenrsquot gone out much at all.ldquoI am grateful for all the kind and lovely comments. I sing often but never had so much reaction.ldquoIrsquove done a live online gig for ELM gig guide with my tribute to Patsy Cline.ldquoThey do live gigs online from lots of performers and raised over pound, for the Royal Hospital for Sick Children in Edinburgh.One fan posted: ldquoThank you for the positivity and keeping us all going.Another said: ldquoLook forward to your song every week.To tune in to Lorrainersquos performances go to her Facebook page at facebook lorraine.mcbrearty videos After last weekrsquos minute silence for NHS workers who have lost their lives in the pandemic, she sang for volunteers from Hickory, based at Eskmills, who are preparing food for vulnerable people as part of Resilient Musselburghrsquos efforts. title: yacht-club-takes-measures-help-stay-afloat
story: The yachts should have been craned into the harbour at the start of April and the committee had an ldquoanxious pre-season discussion to figure out safe ways to continue activities as the coronavirus crisis started to unfold.After the full lockdown, with the boats still on dry land, members have been using Skype on a near weekly basis to plan how to keep the club thriving for the foreseeable and long-term future.Former commodore Mark McClelland has urged members to take part in an online sailing race game called Virtual Regatta.One club member will be asked to take part in a Virtual Regatta e-championship against players from other Scottish clubs and then go on to a UK-wide competition.While playing the game, Fisherrow Yacht Clubparticipants also take part in a virtual Friday Night Bar get-together, enjoying a tipple in their own homes while connected to other participants through Zoom.One of the biggest losses to the club programme is the start-of-the season event called Discover Sailing, formerly known as Push the Boat Out, which was due to take place this Saturday, May .Inez Visser, club spokesperson, said: ldquoIt should have been an open day for non-members to try sailing and to look around the facilities in the club premises.ldquoDiscover Sailing has been the most important means to recruit new members in the last few years.ldquoFYC hopes to be able to recreate something similar later in the summer while taking into account necessary hygiene requirements.She explained: ldquoMany FYC members can sail their dinghies or yachts solo or with family members so, from that aspect, sailing can resume as soon as is permitted.ldquoIn addition,local members can come to the beach already dressed to go out on the water, this would free up space in the changing facilities for those who travel from further away.ldquoCurrently, the biggest challenge is figuring out a way to crew the club safety and race committee power boats without breach of the contamination guidelines.ldquoHowever, many resourceful solutions have been devised to protect people from contamination so FYC is hopeful a solution for watersports can be found soon.She added: ldquoWhile not sailing, the committee has been looking at research information published by the sailing umbrella body, Royal Yachting Association , which has analysed age demographics and water participation in general in the last few years.ldquoUsing the information from RYA, the club is looking forward to how its current activities and club facilities, especially club-owned boats, can be dferently managed to suit the needs of the next generation of sailors.ldquoThis includes not only Generations X, Y and Z, but also third age sailors, as the research highlighted that sailing is well suited to older people because the physical demands are not as great as many other sports.ldquoAt this time, FYC is ever mindful that the club premises are a resource, not only for the sailing club, but for other users such as the Musselburgh Athletics Club runners, Eskmuthe Rowing Club, sea cadets, Fisherrow Harbour and Seafront Association and the Cooking Club.!In addition, there are one-off users such as the Musselburgh Festival beach ride out guests and British Divers Marine Le Rescue training day volunteers.ldquoAll of the users have had their activities impacted and we hope that, as soon as possible, they too will be able resume.Thank you for reading this story. title: superhero-primary-school-teacher-message-difference
story: Alison Blevins, a primary four teacher at the school, posted a welcome back message on social media after the Easter holidays.It read: ldquoWelcome back to the summer term. Please donrsquot feel any pressure to complete work in what are challenging circumstances. Irsquod sooner you went outside and enjoyed the good weather. See you in our virtual classroom ready to be curious, positive, successful and respectful.Attached to the message was a picture of Alison as a superhero, with a cape and buildings drawn around her on the ground in chalk.Two days later she shared a lsquofun Friday challengersquo and asked her pupils to dress up as their favourite superhero.She dressed up as Spiderman and her son took several pictures of her climbing and hanging from ious buildings.Alison, who lives in a bungalow, said her son stood on top of a flat piece of roof to take the images ndash but stressed that she doesnrsquot recommend people try the same at home!Inspiration for the pictures came from an art project she did with her primary four class last year, which saw them lie on the ground, draw around their head, then stand back up and add something to the drawing such as a hat or crazy hair.Then the pupil would lie back down and take a photograph. Other ideas for her pictures came from the social media site Pinterest.Alison said: ldquoItrsquos just a dferent spin on it and Irsquom trying to engage with the pupils as much as possible, really. Itrsquos easy and just a bit of fun.One drawing for an image can take as long as a couple of hours to complete. They are also planned out on a piece of paper to make sure they will fit into the space.While some pictures are based on the topic being looked at that week, others, such as her Spiderman picture, are for entertainment.Alison said: ldquoPeople have responded really well. Itrsquos a dferent way of getting in contact with the children and keeping them engaged in their learning.She hopes to post at least one picture a week.Thank you for reading this story. title: former-power-station-site-become-covid-19-testing-centre
story: East Lothian Council has confirmed that the former Cockenzie Power Station site will be opened and operated by the military as part of the UK Governments Covid- testing programme.No date for when it will start operations has been revealed but it is likely to be within the next week as testing is ramped up as part of plans to ease the current lockdown.It will be the first Covid- testing site of its kind in East Lothian, where an assessment centre has also been operating in Musselburgh since the start of April.The site, which was bought by the local authority from ScottishPower and is currently being marketed for economic investment, was offered up as a potential testing location by the council.The unit will be managed and staffed by military personnel, who would be responsible for its safe operation.Military staff will make appropriate use of PPE and no equipment will be left on site whilst the facility is closed.The council said it expects the facility to operate as a self-contained, drive-through facility. People will remain in their vehicle whilst being tested. Initially, it is understood it would operate over two, three-day periods.Tom Reid, the councils head of infrastructure, said: ldquoWe were asked to identy a potentially suitable site for a drive-through, mobile testing facility to be located."The former Cockenzie Power Station site was identied as a site which could be operated safely by military personnel."This facility would enable key workers who are self-isolating due to them or household members displaying symptoms to undergo testing, which is a vital component of the national response to tackling Covid-."East Lothian Council will continue to play its part and work with partners locally and nationally in dealing with the challenges posed by the emergency.The facility will provide tests for key workers who are self-isolating due to them or household members displaying symptoms.It is understood key workers and their family members will be eligible for testing.Key workers who are, or have a family member who is, symptomatic, can sign up via thehttps:self-referral.test-for-coronavirus.service.gov.uk portal.Cockenzie power stations famous twin chimneys were demolished in a controlled explosion in September, , two years after it had closed. The power station had opened in .

story: Officers were given the description of a man, who was allegedly seen attempting to enter vehicles in Blink OrsquoForth during yesterdayevening and into today .The man is described as being of average build, about five-foot-nine-inches tall, wearing black clothing and a black baseball cap.A spokesman for Police Scotland said: ldquoPolice have a male is custody in relation to this and local officers are appealing for further information andsurrounding properties have CCTV to contact the Police on  quoting incident number  of May .ldquoAt this time, Police wish to remind members of the public to ensure that vehicles are secured whilst left unattended and no valuables are kept within.

title: east-lothian-council-racing-june
story: Groundstaff at the townrsquos award-winning racecourse, who have been furloughed, will temporarily resume work this month to prepare the track for the anticipated fixture.Bill Farnsworth, general manager, said that the racecourse was using the next few weeks to prepare after the UK Government said no sporting events woulduntil June  and the Scottish Government continued lockdown until the end of May.He said: ldquoThe British Horseracing Industry has already done much work on the operational plan for the resumption of horseracing in the UK.ldquoWe will therefore use the forthcoming weeks to finalise the plan for ato racing at Musselburgh, hopefully in June, however horseracing will only resume at Musselburgh when it is safe to do so and with the full support of the UK and Scottish Governments.Mr Farnsworth said that racingrsquoswould be under strict restrictions and behind closed doors, similar to what is already happening in France and Germany.He said the hope is that Musselburgh can resume its schedule fixture list with a race on June , which had already been in its diary.He said: ldquoIf horseracing resumes in June, we hope to stage Musselburghrsquos scheduled fixture on Saturday thJune butthe advice is that June is too early to stage horseracing in Scotland, we will wait until for the appropriate time and for the greenlight from the UK and Scottish Governments.Horse-racing ed in France this week giving hope to trainers that Britain will not be far behind.A joint letter to Scottish Sports Minister Joe Fitzpatrick, MSP, from East Lothian MP Kenny MacAskill and MPs Allan Dorans, Angela Crawley and Pete Wishart, who represent racecourses in Hanmilton, Ayr and Perth urges a quick restart to racing when safe to do so.It says: ldquoRacing finds itself in a unique position compared to other Scottish sports in that our equine athletes, cherished so highly by those in the industry, have remained in training during thepandemic and will therefore be able to come back on shorter notice than the human athletes inother sports.ldquoWhen it is safe to do so, ato racing is the best way of getting the economic cogs of theindustry turning once more, and kickstart the benefits to the Scottish economy that horseracingbrings, even in a behind closed doors environment.ldquoTherefore, we ask that you please accelerateyour talks with Scottish racing to ensure that a risk managedcan take place as soon aspossible and that ato racing behind closed doors in Scotland does not get unduly delayedcompared to the rest of the United Kingdom.

title: mcdonalds-reveal-safety-rules-customers-ahead-gradual-reopening
story: The move comes after announcing a delivery-only service, followed by the reopening of a number of drive-thrus later this month.What are McDonalds doing McDonaldrsquos is to reopen its first  drive-through restaurants as early as next week as it pushes forward with its reopening plans.It comes as fast food rival Subway reopens more than  of its UK stores on Tuesday for delivery and takeaway as it serves customers for the first time since the lockdown.McDonaldrsquos will open its first  pilot restaurants from am on Wednesday, May , for deliveries only.The fast food chain said it intends to begin the next phase of its reopening plans next week by opening  sites in the UK and Ireland for drive-through customers only on Wednesday, May .It said it plans to reopen all of its drive-through sites by early June, in line with Government guidelines.What additional rules will be in place for customers McDonaldrsquos said it will cap the amount customers can spend to pound per car and will ask customers to use contactless payment.This will take place alongside safety measures the chain already announced, such as contactless thermometers for staff, Perspex screens and protective equipment.The company called for customers to be ldquopatient and supportive of staff as sites reopen, warning that service ldquowill not be as quick as you might be used to as workers adjust to the changes.What have McDonalds said Paul Pomroy, McDonaldrsquos chief executive officer for UK and Ireland, said: ldquoThere has been an incredible response to news of our reopening and we know many of you are eager for us to extend our reopening plans at a faster pace.ldquoThe wellbeing of our employees, suppliers and delivery partnersrsquo couriers is my top priority and we will only extend our plans at a pace that enables us to create a safe working environment for our teams.ldquoAs we get accustomed to the new processes and procedures, we will look to reopen more restaurants, for longer hours and reintroduce more menu items.ldquoBut only when I am confident we can do so whilst maintaining the new procedures we have introduced for the protection of our people.What are other food outlets doing Meanwhile, Subway said it has reopened more than  stores on Tuesday, May , in the first phase of its reopening programme.It said the sites have reopened with new operational and social distancing safety measures to protect customers and staff.The chain said customers will be able to have food from these sites delivered via Just Eat, Uber Eats or Deliveroo.Colin Hughes, country director for Subway UK and Ireland, said: ldquoEverybody in our Subway family and the wider communities they serve, has shown great resilience in adapting to these challenging times that we currently find ourselves in.ldquoWe are extremely grateful for their ongoing support in anticipation of this next phase of our gradual reopening, which will enable us to continue to serve our communities and frontline workers, who have helped us all so much in recent weeks.ldquoThe weeks and months ahead will continue to be challenging for everyone and Subway will play its part in supporting the new normal whatever that may look and feel like.

title: donations-pouring-help-north-berwicks-scottish-seabird-centre
story: Started last Wednesday , the centre launched the urgent appeal with an aim to raise pound, by the end of July, which will help see it through lockdown after Covid- closed the attractions visitor centre and stopped its income.So far, pound, has been raised on the online JustGiving page but almost pound, has been donated in total.Opened  years ago, the charity is under threat and faces closurethe required amount is not raised.Those at the Seabird Centre hoped their target could be reached through grant and government funding, but without signicant public funding this will not be possible.Susan Davies, CEO of the Scottish Seabird Centre said: ldquoIn response to Covid-, we launched the first public appeal in the  year history of our charity on May , with the backing of both Chris Packham and Simon King.ldquoWe are delighted with the generosity already shown by the public and our loyal members with nearly pound, already donated.ldquoThe warm messages of support we have received have given the team a real morale boost and hope for the future too.ldquoWe still have a big challenge to meet our pound, target by the end of July, through a combination of the public appeal and emergency funding applications but we remain hopeful for the future. title: lothian-buses-announces-changes-services
story: Its number  service, which links parts of Musselburgh to the west side of Edinburgh, now sees frequency improved to every  minutes from Monday-Saturday during the day.There is minor timetable changes on the  service which goes from Tranent to Edinburgh through Prestonpans and Musselburgh.On EastCoast Buses, the  service, which goes from Dunbar to Edinburgh through places such as Haddington, Tranent and Wallyford, sees daytime frequency increased to  minutes from Edinburgh to Haddington, the hourly service to and from Dunbar will be maintained.On the  Pencaitland to Edinburgh service, there is a revised timetable to coordinate with the . The last journey from Edinburgh and Pencaitland has been withdrawn.A revised timetable has been introduced on the  North Berwick to Edinburgh service, including an additional morning peak journey from Longniddry to Edinburgh on Mondays and Saturdays.There is currently no change on the  service from Musselburgh to Roslin.Nigel Serafini, interim managing director at Lothian Buses, said: ldquoOver the past six weeks, our services have provided vital links for those who require to travel for work or to obtain essentials such as food and medicine."Our teams have continued to monitor customer travel patterns and have listened to both customer and colleague feedback."Today we are announcing additional revisions to our Critical Services Network which will better meet the needs of key workers and those for whom travel remains essential.ldquoEvery team across our business has continued to go above and beyond to provide these vital services and my thanks go to each and every one of them both on the frontline and behind the scenes."I would also like to thank our customers who have shown an enormous amount of support and understanding throughout what continues to be an incredibly challenging operational time.

title: hollywood-stars-appear-outlander-returns-east-lothian
story: Filming for the worldwide hit took place in spring last year but details about what was shot could not be revealed until after its episode had aired.East Linton is no stranger to the Outlander cast and crew as Preston Mill has also been used as a filming location.While Outlander star Sam Heughan ndash who was not in East Linton this time ndash was part of a fundraising campaign which helped raise pound, to repair the millrsquos water wheel.The Mart, formerly a market place for local farmers and traders, is now an arts and events venue. It had been booked for weddings this summer, but these have been delayed until next year due to the coronavirus outbreak.Outlanderrsquos programmersquos location manager contacted Melissa Wearmouth, The Martrsquos site manager, to arrange the filming.Melissa told the Courier: ldquoThey wanted something with our shape of building and were finding it hard to come across.Our building is the last one of its kind in Scotland so is quite unique .ldquoOne of the guys spoke to a friend and mentioned us and then the people from the show got in contact.Crew were there for three weeks to set up equipment for only one dayrsquos filming. Stars including Billy Boyd, of Lord of the Rings fame, Edward Speleers , James Dohertyand Andy Apollowere spotted.Melissa added that The Martrsquos car park was full and there were a lot of people about, such as security, catering and lighting staff.Filming also attracted some fans of the show, who hoped to catch a glimpse of their favourite characters.Work to restore the building, which included laying a new floor and painting the exterior, had just been finished.Melissa said: ldquoThey were pretty easy going. They had to change little things, like laying an old floor.ldquoWe put the new floor on top of the old cobbles and put in a glass centrepiece so you could still see the cobbles in the middle we needed a new floor for events and stuff.ldquoIt took us a long time to restore the building and its original features we tried to keep as many of the older features as possible.ldquo[The Outlander team] put a temporary floor on top so they could have dirt and things like that ndash they needed it to look more like a tavern.The Mart is featured in series five of the show, which is out now on Amazon Prime, at the end of episode two, which was first broadcast on February .Melissa admitted she had not watched the show previously but does now!

title: former-royal-marine-conquers-everest-back-garden
story: Kenny Simm, , climbed a rope and abseiled down it in his garden on the Lennoxlove Estate, near Haddington,  times, completing a total of , metres, the same height as Mount Everest in the Himalayas.He completed his challenge over  hours, starting at am on April  and finishing at am on April .He did not sleep in between but did occasionally stop for refreshment breaks.Kenny said: ldquoI think it was just a spur of the moment thing.ldquoI came up with the idea four days before I started it so didnrsquot do any prior training.ldquoWhen I was with the Marines I went off-shore and saw all these challenges people were doing and thought it would be a good thing to do.ldquoI wanted to do something a bit dferent and a bit special for charity and also to challenge myself.He had a four-metre-long rope attached to the side of his shed that he intended to use for the challenge. . . until the rope snapped during a testing session.Kenny was climbing the rope at the time and fell four metres to the ground but was not badly hurt.He then contacted a friend who came to his house and built an eight-metre-high scaffolding structure in his garden specially for the challenge.Every time he landed on solid ground, he would record his run to make sure he completed the , journeys needed to reach the required distance:  times up and  times down.While the journey down was a simple abseil, Kenny, who used to be on the British bobsleigh team and competed in strongman events, had to pull himself to the top.Kenny, who is originally from Shetland and is dad to seven-year-old Hugo, was a Royal Marine for  years.He now works for Viridor as a mechanical fitter at the Dunbar energy recovery facility.He said: ldquoI think the Royal Marines helped a little bit. Being part of the Marines is like an exclusive club and I had that prior training.He added: ldquoNot sleeping was the hardest bit. When I asked my we about it she said, lsquoYoursquore not going to do thatrsquo.ldquoShe set an alarm every two hours and was checking on me to make sure I was still alive. I made pasta and made sure to keep my food and drink intake up. I had music playing too.ldquoIt was pretty tough, especially the first two hours. I kept thinking lsquowhat kind of challenge is this going to bersquo and wondered how I was going to do it for  hours.ldquoThere was added pressure because we had highlighted it on social media.Kenny is raising money for the NHS who, he says, are ldquodoing amazing work, are ldquorisking their lives and ldquohave never had that [proper] recognition.Hersquos raised almost pound, so far.His mother-in-law Carol Fitzgerald is a retired NHS worker and sister-in-law Karen McQuade works in a coronavirus ward at Royal Infirmary of Edinburgh.Hearing their stories also inspired him.It took Kenny two days to fully recover from his challenge, which gave him blisters and cramps in his arms and legs.He added: ldquoIrsquom glad I did it but I wonrsquot be doing it again.Anyone wishing to donate can do so at www.justgiving fundraising kennysimm-climbeverestfor-nhs

title: veteran-musicians-mark-ve-day-doorsteps
story: Alastair Knowles BEM played the lsquoLast Postrsquo on the bugle from the front door of his Stoneyhill home and pipe major Stewart Braby performed lsquoBattlersquos Orsquoerrsquo at the Mall near his house in Inveresk Road last Friday.Mr Knowles said he was asked by Iain Clark, from Musselburgh, a Depute Lieutenant of East Lothian, to mark the end of the two -minute silence at am that day by ringing the bell at Northesk Church in Musselburgh, which he duly did.Mr Knowles also heard from Bruno Peek, VE Day  Pageant Master, who was keen to keep as much of the national programme going as possible amidst the coronavirus pandemic.The events were arranged to mark the th anniversary of Victory in Europe Day ndash the day celebrating the formal acceptance by the Allies of the Nazisrsquo unconditional surrender of their armed forces, on Tuesday,  May , marking the end of the Second World War in Europe.Buglers and trumpeters were still urged to sound the lsquoLast Postrsquo, as planned, at .pm, and pipers to play lsquoBattlersquos Orsquoerrsquo at pm.Mr Knowles followed his uncle into the Boysrsquo Brigade in the mid-s.Since then he has become a key part of the group, becoming a bugler and leading drummer in the Penicuik and Musselburgh Boysrsquo Brigade Pipe Band.He was Town Champion at the  Riding of the Marches in Musselburgh, before being appointed chairman of the  event.He is also a former president of the Old Musselburgh Club.He received the BEM for services to the community in Musselburgh.Mr Braby, pipe major with the Penicuik  Musselburgh Boysrsquo Brigade Pipe Band, is also pipe major of the massed bands at the Boysrsquo Brigade Beating Retreat at Edinburgh Castle.Mr Knowles said: ldquoLater in the evening my we Lily and I, as our daily exercise outing, took a walk to Northesk, where the third member of the church,Lorraine McBrearty, added her contribution with the singing of lsquoWersquoll Meet Againrsquo only yards from her home on Bridge Street at pm.He added: ldquoIt was a busy but fulfilling day.
